title: ”Poems, Bells and Synths”
description:
CULTURE NIGHT, FRIDAY 20th September 2024 at 8pm.
The Dominican 800th, Drogheda 1294-2024
Drogheda's Musicians and Poets perform in a
FREE CONCERT at the Augustinian Church, Shop St.
''Poems, Bells and Synths''
The Augustinian Church in Shop St, possesses a unique Bell Tree of 40 chimes which is used during mass and rituals. The Bell Tree is tuned to C and G pentatonic scales. Michael Holohan, composer, will premiere a new work called Sounds from a Cloister using the bells to commemorate 800 years of the Dominican Order in Drogheda (1224-2024). The piece will be celebratory in nature and will acknowledge the great contribution of the Dominicans to the history of medieval Drogheda and not forgetting the huge contribution also made by The Augustinian and Franciscan orders. The composition will integrate the sounds of the other church bells of Drogheda i.e. the bells of St. Peter's Church of Ireland, St. Peter's Catholic Church and The Tholsel. The sounds of these bells will be recorded on tape and mixed with the live sounds in the church. This live performance will be accompanied by percussion. The audience will be surrounded with 'retro synthesiser sounds', percussion and bells thus giving our listeners a unique experience of 'spatial music.'
The performers will be Breifne Holohan, John Mc Crea, Grace Dillon, Trudy Maguire, Martin Shields, Joanne Kieran, Juliet Barrow, Barry Leahy, Stephen Higgins, Brendan Leahy and Michael Holohan, artistic director.
SJ Mc Ardle, singer songwriter, will perform songs from his CD and song cycle Port.
The composer Breifne Holohan will perform pieces for electric guitar and electronics including Guth na Gaoithe, an improvisation featuring samples of Bronze age horns by Ancient Music Ireland.
Between the musical items readings will be given by the widely published Drogheda poets Susan Connolly, Roger Hudson, Emir Ní Daibhís, Paddy Dillon, John O'Rourke and Tomas De Faoite.
With the support of Create Louth and Culture Night
Admission: Free , no booking required. A wine reception will take place after the concert
fullAddress: Shop Street, Moneymore, Drogheda, County Louth, Ireland

title: ‘At War With Mercy’ by John MacKenna and Angela Keogh
description: 'At War With Mercy' is a work inspired by the songs and writings of the late Canadian songwriter and poet Leonard Cohen and developed by the writers John MacKenna and Angela Keogh. 'At War With Mercy' is a musical and dramatic exploration of war, peace and mercy through Leonard Cohen's songs and the stories developed by Keogh and MacKenna. With singer Katie Jacques; singer/guitarist Shane Sullivan; percussionist Dave Day and actors Angela Keogh and John MacKenna, the show is a life-affirming journey that echoes with hope, warmth, redemption and peace.
fullAddress: Athy Library, Convent Lane, Athy, Co. Kildare, R14 DK33, Ireland

title: ‘Everything is Grand, and I’m Completely Okay’ by Conor Burke
description:
The Moat Club, in collaboration with Conor Burke and Eruption Collective, is thrilled to announce the return of EVERYTHING IS GRAND, AND I’M COMPLETELY OKAY.

Malachy has just turned twenty-five and he has a few things to say about that. Dealing with the death of his younger brother, he is struggling to come to terms with all that he is, and everything that he’s not. Working as a customer support advisor in a call centre at a bin disposal company and experiencing many different escapades with his best friend Pauline, Malachy is eager to take some time to reflect on and move on with his life. He quickly comes to realise, however, that it’s not as easy as it seems on paper. A play about growing up, and the lessons we learn along the way.

Written & performed by Conor Burke, who received a nomination for the Micheál Mac Liammóir Award for Outstanding Lead Performance by an Actor in a Play at the 2023 International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival and directed by IFTA nominee Lesley Conroy. Originally developed with the aid of Dublin Fringe Festival.

title: ‘In ár gcroithe go deo’ 2020 Legacy Cross Celebration
description:
'In ár gcroithe go deo' (In our hearts forever) is a special legacy collaborative arts project undertaken by the Tudor Artisan Hub in 2020. This was to honour 22 loved ones from or connected to Carrick-on-Suir who passed away in 2020, under very difficult conditions, during the Covid-19 pandemic lockdown.

In 2022 the artwork on this outdoor installation was touched up by the artists involved. For Culture Night 2024, to try and preserve this historic legacy installation, artists in the community are once again coming together to repair and restore the weathered art legacy pieces on this special cross. New signage will be erected, with a link to a digital platform telling the story of the project, enabling this unique arts installation to also be accessible virtually.

On Culture Night, a special blessing celebration will be held at the Legacy Cross at 6pm, this is a FREE public event, no booking required. All are welcome.

No booking required. All are welcome.

title: ‘Longest Way Round, Shortest Way Home’ Exhibition Tours
description:
This Culture Night, the friendly team from Temple Bar Gallery + Studios will give an introduction to 'Longest Way Round, Shortest Way Home', two off-site solo exhibitions by artists Yuri Pattison and Liliane Puthod located in the unique surroundings of The Pumphouse at Dublin Port, the site of a former graving docks.

The site-specific immersive exhibitions use forms of artistic storytelling to offer points of connection between geographic, economic and technical networks. They use the symbolism of rivers and seas as places of impermanence that describe transitory relationships through, and outside of the flow of time.

Booking is essential. Families are welcome, however children must be under adult supervision.

'Longest Way Round, Shortest Way Home', is produced and curated by Temple Bar Gallery + Studios, in partnership with Dublin Port Company.

title: ‘Looking for Happiness in Co. Cavan – Final Part’
description:
Building on the success of the previous phases, "Looking for Happiness in Co. Cavan - Final Part" aims to complete the portrait series by capturing an additional 40 portraits from the communities of Ballyconnell, Belturbet, Bailieborough, Cootehill, and Cavan Town. This final instalment will create a comprehensive collection of 100 portraits, highlighting the diverse fabric of County Cavan and exploring the shared pursuit of happiness among its residents.

Between 01/07 and 01/09 I will travel to these towns to photograph individuals, capturing intimate and expressive headshots that reflect their unique stories. Participants will answer the question, "What makes you happy? Where do you find happiness?" These personal responses will accompany their portraits, offering deeper insights into their lives and perspectives.
This final exhibition phase aims to foster unity, empathy, and understanding by celebrating the diversity and commonalities within the community.
fullAddress: Cavan County Council, Farnham Street, Keadew, Cavan, Ireland

title: ‘The Borderlands Personality Disorder’
description:
Join us for a powerful and movement-based performance by Niamh McPhillips, a neurodivergent artist from Carrickmacross, Monaghan. This piece explores her experiences growing up in the border town and her relationship with the Cavan/Monaghan border and the North.
The performance will include strong language and references to smuggling, the IRA, and the Monaghan Bombings of 1974. Music from the band Soft Launch will play in the background, enhancing the atmosphere. Niamh will wear a black balaclava, O’Neill football shorts, and both Monaghan and Cavan GAA jerseys. The performance will feature dance, spoken word, and the poem “Primrose” by Patrick Kavanagh.

PLEASE NOTE: Not suitable for children

description:

Cavan, in 1884. This production by Paddy Farrelly has been enhanced with live musicians to underscore the movement and dialogue, adding depth to the performance.

This moving piece is being presented to the wider public in Shercock for the first time. Do not miss the chance to witness a powerful and emotional retelling of a significant local event.

title: ‘UNCLE ERIC’, A SHORT FILM PREMIERE
description:
Join us for an engaging and insightful screenwriting workshop, led by the award-winning writer, Darren Donohue. This complimentary workshop will explore dramatic techniques and narrative strategies, offering invaluable tips for aspiring screenwriters.

Following the workshop, enjoy a special free screening of the short film ‘Uncle Eric’. 'Uncle Eric' was produced by Carlow’s Creative Productions and features a talented local cast. It is written and directed by Darren.

Chaired by RTÉ broadcaster Brenda Donohue, the screening will be followed by a Q&A session with the cast and crew, providing a unique opportunity to gain insights into the filmmaking process.
fullAddress: IMC Cinema Carlow, Barrack Street, Carlow, Ireland

title: ‘Ampersands & Mullions’ – Talk by Orla Murphy, Architect, on Traditional Shop Fronts and Signage of Donegal.
description:
Join Orla Murphy, award-winning architect and UCD Assistant Professor of Architecture, for an informal talk about Traditional Shop Fronts and Signage of Donegal, at Ernest Speer’s on Letterkenny Main Street.

Taking Ernest Speer’s beautiful shop front as an example, this short talk will explore some of the elements of shop fronts and signage that give our towns their unique character and distinctiveness. From colours, proportion, material, typography and craftsmanship, our shop fronts represent the local culture, stories and memory of place. Be sure to share your own story of your favourite shop fronts in Letterkenny with us at the event.

FREE copies of the Donegal Traditional Shop Fronts and Signage booklet, written by Orla and commissioned as part of the implementation of the County Donegal Heritage Plan, will be available. No booking required.
fullAddress: ernest speer, Letterkenny, County Donegal, Ireland

title: ‘Critters’ – A Sculpture and Performance Trail
description:
Join us for an unforgettable evening as Inishowen Carnival presents a sculpture and performance trail through Letterkenny Town Park. Celebrating the wonders of life on planet earth and of the world of insects in particular, CRITTERS tries to imagine what life would look like if evolution had taken a slightly different direction, if insects had looked a little more human, if humans had looked a little more insect like?

Featuring three huge humanoid insect characters, light sculptures, walkabout characters, the brilliant Fusion Donegal dance company, music and fire performances, don’t miss this truly magical experience that celebrates the richness of culture, creativity, and the marvels of our world.
fullAddress: Letterkenny Town Park, Ballyboe Glencar, Letterkenny, County Donegal, Ireland

Each piece encourages reflection and suggests a deep connection with the land. Her contemporary artworks are full of energy, joy and atmosphere. The thick oil paint and rich textures create a sensory experience, inviting viewers to immerse themselves in the beauty of the magical Irish landscape.

title: ‘Filling The Well’
description:
Ad Personam Cultural Events Ltd, invite you to 'Filling the Well', the first Culture Night event to take place in the village of Rosslare Strand as part of Culture Night 2024. This event marks a unique collaboration of diverse community groups, multicultural performers and includes residents of Rosslare’s Direct Provision Centre.

'Filling the Well' is an invitation to people of every culture to contribute their music, stories and ideas to invest in a multicultural experience in the community of Rosslare. A cultural song share will take place at 6pm at Scoil Mhuire Rosslare, followed by a candlelight walk to St. Brioc's Well at 7.30pm.

St. Brioc, a 5th Century visitor to Rosslare, is widely attributed the honour of giving Rosslare its name. St. Brioc’s Well is situated in the scenic Burrow of Rosslare and will be the final focal point of this unique event. Rosláir, meaning ‘middle peninsula’ is in the heart of the district. This event, ‘Filling the Well’, culminates at this site where the name of Rosslare will be celebrated as an inclusive, culturally diverse and creative community.

Want to take part in this exciting event?

If you are interested in performing or attending this event, please email: fillingthewellrosslare2024@gmail.com

Performers, please include a brief description of your performance genre and number of participants.

Tickets for this event are free but places are limited.
fullAddress: Scoil Mhuire NS Rosslare, Bearlough, Rosslare Strand, County Wexford, Ireland

title: ‘Herbert Simms – an architect for the people’ plus live trad music
description:
architect and his legacy.

In the 19th century, Dublin’s teeming slums were regarded as the worst in Europe. To tackle the crisis, Herbert Simms was appointed the city’s first housing architect in the early 1930s. In a sixteen year period between 1932 and 1948, he and his Dublin Corporation team built an astounding 17,000 homes, some as inner city flat complexes and others as houses in newly-created suburbs such as Crumlin and Cabra.

Like the city’s acclaimed Georgian squares, the Simms-designed Corporation flats in particular have stood the test of time, adding a touch of Art Deco and Modernist glamour to the inner city streets and, not before time, a number of them have been added to the city’s list of protected structures in recent year.

In this talk, St Mobhi's Parish take a look at Simms work and consider what can be learned from the 1930s approach to a severe urban housing crisis.
fullAddress: St. Mobhi's Church, Church St, Glasnevin, Dublin 9, Ireland

title: ‘In Search of Hy-Brasil’- Peter Carroll, Peter Cody, Elizabeth Hatz, Mary Laheen and Joseph Mackey
description:
The 2024 edition of the Architecture at the Edge Festival will include the presentation of ‘In Search of Hy-Brasil – Ireland’s national pavilion at the Venice Architecture Biennale 2023’. The project examines the relationship between the islands of Ireland and their natural environment and puts our islands’ diverse communities, culture, and experiences right at the centre of the discourse surrounding our shared future.

Curated by a team of five architects: Peter Carroll, Peter Cody, Elizabeth Hatz, Mary Laheen, and Joseph Mackey; Ireland’s national pavilion at the Venice Architecture Biennale 2023, In Search of Hy-Brasil, derives from an intense engagement with the islands of Ireland and is a direct provocation to all of us to reimagine the vast combined territory of land and ocean we call our home.

We are an island nation facing an uncertain future. The challenges of climate change, renewable energy, ethical food production and biodiversity must be met quickly, with purpose, renewing the lost equilibrium between ourselves and the natural world. In making this adjustment, our islands’ inventiveness in the face of adversity and creativity in response to having less provides us with the necessary tools and narratives to inspire more sustainable ways of living.

Join us on Culture Night 2024 for Island Celebrations! Follow @ArchAtTheEdge for updates.
fullAddress: 15 Market Street, Galway, Ireland

title: ‘Landmark As Witness’, a Public Artwork by Jialin Long
description:
'Landmark as Witness' is a series of flags commissioned by Temple Bar Gallery + Studios, hoisted along Wellington Quay for Culture Night. This year, artist Jialin Long has conceived the flag designs using the idea of the landmark as a witness, inspired by the Ha'penny Bridge in Dublin.

‘Water symbolises the flow of people travelling from one place to another, while the bridge
represents the connection between different cultures, fostering friendship and understanding. In my studio in Temple Bar, I am continually fascinated by the diverse crowd passing each day. The Ha'penny Bridge stands as a silent observer of the unique stories and backgrounds of every individual who crosses it.’

The flags can be seen flying over the Liffey on Wellington Quay for the month of September. There will be an accompanying drop-in workshop at Temple Bar Gallery + Studios on Culture Night.

title: ‘The Charm’: Storytelling and Songs
description:
Visit the National Leprechaun Museum on Culture Night for a rare glimpse into their captivating storytelling practice.

How can you protect someone from a fairy's dark love charm? Discover the sinister tale of a group of residents who become convinced that the frog they've encountered is not just an ordinary amphibian but a fairy in disguise. This enchanting and absurdist narrative, inspired by Peadar Ó Ceannabháin's Amhrán An Frag, will transport you into a world where the lines between the mundane and the magical blur. Immerse yourself in the melodic songs that breathe life into our folklore. Don't miss this chance to experience the whimsical charm of Irish folklore at the National Leprechaun Museum. Written by Sarah McKenna Dunne.

Each session is 15-20 minutes in duration. Make sure to secure your spot early as spaces are limited.
Recommended for ages 16 and up.

title: “Beara” – Tara Viscardi (Harp) & Robert Harvey (Flute)
description:
Harpist Tara Viscardi and flautist Robert Harvey launched their album Beara in April 2024, a project which pairs contemporary, original compositions inspired by the Beara Peninsula in the South West of Ireland, with tunes collected and written on the peninsula since the 18th century. It also draws inspiration from the legend of Princess Beara, the Spanish Princess who it is said married Owen Mór, King of Ireland, around 120 AD and who gave the area its name.

The project has been showcased at the Irish Embassy UK, Dublin City Assembly House, London Irish Centre, Tuamgraney Harp Festival, Return to London Town Festival, the Wales International Harp Festival, Kenmare Buttermarket, Cornstown House and the World Harp Congress, Cardiff, generously supported by Culture Ireland. The album was recorded on location in Dawros Church, Co. Kerry by producer Laoise O' Brien and engineer Ben Rawlins and is funded by Kerry County Council Arts, Small Investments Ltd., the Wales International Harp Festival and Beara Distillery.

A multiple prize winner, Tara has performed and recorded at venues including the Wigmore Hall, Abbey Road Studios, the National Concert Hall Dublin, Áras an Uachtaráin, St John's Smith Square, the Mansion House and the Irish Embassy in London.

Seven times All-Ireland Champion, Robert released his critically acclaimed solo flute album Feochán in 2020. He has toured internationally with Dónal Lunny’s band Cíorras, the Traditional Arts Collective, The Katerina Garcia Band and The National Folk Orchestra of Ireland.

For any queries please contact westwicklowfestival@gmail.com.
fullAddress: Russborough House & Park, Russborough, Blessington, County Wicklow, Ireland

title: “A Passage Underlined” Recorded Poetry – Remixed Live
description:
“A Passage Underlined” Recorded Poetry - Remixed Live is a mixed-media presentation by Katie from the Pleiades (Katie Cogan) consisting of recordings of poets and authors combined with electronic music.

Delivered live on Culture Night to mark the transition of the Salmon Bookshop and Literary Centre from its former location on Parliament Street to its new and permanent home on Main Street Ennistymon. It highlights the blending of old and new, analogue and digital, spoken and sung, with a juxtaposition that highlights the importance of brick and mortar institutions in their support of artists in this era of the online and the digital. By mixing the recordings of a selection of spectacular poets with joyful electronic music designed to be danced to,

A Passage Underlined highlights poetry and prose as living, evolving, community-supporting and community-driven practices. Six poets and a selection of their poetry will feature in the event. Two poets to be selected through an open call so please keep an eye on Katie Cogan’s Instagram (@katie_cogan) or email katriencogan@gmail.com for information about the open call if you are interested in submitting.

Katie from the Pleiades is a DJ, astrologer and poet who is fascinated with invocation of words and sounds as connective threads between beings and the forces of nature whom we share this realm with.

Doors from 8pm.
Performance from 8.30pm - 10pm
Wheelchair accessible.
Suitable for teens 16+.
venueName: Salmon Bookshop & Literary Centre, Main Street Ennistymon, V95 XD35, Co. Clare.
fullAddress: The Salmon Bookshop & Literary Centre, Main Street, Ennistimon, Ennistymon, County Clare, Ireland

title: “Notorious Bad Characters” | Crime and Clemency: Women in Irish Prisons 1920s – 1930s
description:
The Department of Justice, in collaboration with the Irish Prison Service, invites the public to an exhibition displaying fascinating records of women incarcerated by the state during the early 20th Century.

Through displays of detailed historical records, visitors will be provided with a rich narrative and insight into the experiences of a selection of notable women in Irish prisons, exploring their journeys and hardships of the prison systems, their convictions, punishment and the pleas for clemency from family and communities. It also provides an opportunity to examine the historical and social context of this era and draw comparisons with our contemporary prison systems and rehabilitation.

An additional exhibition of creative works by women of the Dóchas Centre will also be on display.
fullAddress: Dublin, D02 HK52, Ireland

title: “The Irish Review – Creative Responses” Curated by Melissa Ryan for the North Tipperary Artists’ Collective in the Thomas MacDonagh Hedge School 2024
description:
Join us on Culture Night for the launch of an art exhibition titled “The Irish Review - Creative Responses" curated by Melissa Ryan for the North Tipperary Artists’ Collective as part of the Thomas MacDonagh Hedge School 2024.

Twenty professional and amateur artists have drawn inspiration from The Irish Review magazines published between 1911-1914 in the Museum’s collection. The artists have visually interpreted the words of writers in The Irish Review from the page into contemporary artworks in a unique collaborative collection.

This exhibition will be inclusive of an array of mixed media, including oils, acrylics, water colours and textiles. The exhibition will run until November. The artwork will be for sale and the museum will not take any commission.

Culture Night also includes readings from the work developed in the Hedge School’s Creative Writing Workshop held on 18 & 19 September, also in response to The Irish Review material in the Collection.

title: “Voices Of Tomorrow Take 2” – Waterford’s Youth Advisory Climate Council
description:
Social issues like climate change and equal rights, and the challenges they pose, can be scary topics and thus lead to inaction. Waterford’s Youth Advisory Climate Council (YACC) are bridging this gap in the second instalment of their open mic night, “Voices Of Tomorrow Take 2” a free social issue themed open mic night in St. Patrick’s Gateway Centre, Waterford at 7.30pm 21st September. This open mic is open to all creatives. Last year there was a comedy set, spoken word, poetry, singers and bands all featuring local creatives and artists. It’s a fun and creative way to encourage people to speak out in a safe space. Making their voices heard by the community and decision makers.
The YACC are eager to involve all communities in the conversation about our home, how we can protect it and make Waterford more sustainable and climate conscious. This shared space is a fantastic opportunity for the people of Waterford to interact with the topic of climate change and other social issues creatively and meaningfully, to express this to decision makers and to develop relationships for working towards a better future together.

This event is an opportunity to express thoughts and ideas for change.

The YACC is made up of passionate climate activists aged 16-35 who wish to work together with decision makers and the creative community to make Waterford an even better city. We hope you will attend the event for a chance to express YOUR thoughts, opinions, hopes and ideas in your creative style.
fullAddress: St. Patrick's Gateway Centre, Patrick Street, Waterford, Ireland

title: 18 Ormond Quay Upper – 1840s Merchant Shop-House
description:
Visit 18 Ormond Quay Upper, a traditional Dublin 1840s merchant shop-house saved and restored over a three-year period by Dublin Civic Trust. This demonstration of best conservation practice secured the prestigious Europa Nostra Award/European Heritage Award 2021 for reviving over-the-shop living while respecting the building's special character.

Explore the traditionally decorated upper floor rooms, hung with authentic wallpapers and furnished with mahogany furniture of the mid-19th century, while taking in sweeping views of the River Liffey. A ground floor shop exhibition explains the conservation process, research and the many traditional skills employed in restoring the building. Staff will be on hand to answer any questions as you enjoy your self-guided visit through this beautiful slice of historic Dublin.

Engage in creating a communal paint project ‘Timeline - KCAT 25’, screen print Sinead Fahy’s commissioned commemorative designs, and participate in visual arts workshops led by KCAT's learning programme. Enjoy screenings of "FeelR" by Luka Grocvic, directed by Susie Lamb, and "The Waterboys" by Jim Rohan and Gary Commerford, celebrating diversity and resilience. Explore Equinox Theatre Company's journey through an archival exhibition. Activities run from 4pm onwards, fostering community engagement and supporting Kilkenny's night-time economy.

title: 30 Plays in 60 Minutes
description:
30 Plays in 60 Minutes is an experimental form of theatre pioneered by Greg Allen and the Neo-Futurists, and the goal, as the name implies, is to perform 30 different plays in 60 minutes. All plays take place in the room, and everything performed is the truth­–no characters. Each audience member receives a menu as they walk in. Look on that menu, you will see a list of plays. There are 30 plays. There are 30 numbers hanging above the performers heads. Each number corresponds to a play on the menu. The audience choose the order of the show. Some plays are funny, others serious, others just bizarre. Audience and performers are in this together, and our common enemy is time. We’ll have 60 minutes on the clock.
Ready? ...
fullAddress: Electric Galway, Abbeygate Street Upper, Galway, Ireland

title: 33RPM Record Store – Upcycling Record Workshop
description:
Upcycling the record: Cleaning, Conserving, and Reimagining Vinyl

This workshop focuses on the preservation and creative repurposing of vinyl records. Participants will learn proper cleaning and conservation techniques to extend the lifespan of their records and explore their cultural and historical significance as musical archives. The session delves into the value of records beyond sound, showcasing their role as cultural artifacts. Attendees will also discover various ways to upcycle damaged or unwanted records into unique art pieces or functional objects, such as bowls, clocks, or jewelry. This handson workshop is designed to appeal to music lovers, artists, collectors, and sustainability enthusiasts, aiming to inspire a deeper appreciation for vinyl records while providing practical skills in conservation and creative reuse, blending music history with sustainable art practices.

One session every 30min

description:
The Department of Justice is proud to present a 3D Virtual and Oral History Tour.

From its beginning as the Department of Home Affairs and its influence on Irish culture through the Censorship Board, this Department has a rich history that we want to share and make accessible to all. The 3D Virtual Tour of 51 St. Stephen’s Green gives exclusive, interactive behind the scenes access so you can explore this historically and architecturally significant building. You can explore some of the building’s most notable rooms, see the Minister's Office, the Minister of State’s Office, the Secretary General’s office and visit the boardroom, all from the comfort of your own home.

In addition, you can learn more about the pre-history of the Department through a video presentation. The presentation contains clips from old newsreels, photographs, and more (narrated in Irish with English subs).

title: 5th Annual Culture Night ÍOVA Photography Collective present: “Echoes of Ireland: Literature in Light and Lens”
description:
For the past five years, the ÍOVA Photography Collective has brought together photographers from around the country for Culture Night Dublin, fostering a community focused on authentic representation and visual storytelling.

By bridging the gap between literature and photography, ‘Echoes of Ireland: Literature in Light and Lens’ offers a multi-sensory experience that deepens the appreciation of Irish cultural heritage and invites viewers to see familiar stories in new and evocative ways. This exhibit has invited photographers to choose a poem, short story, or literary excerpt from Irish literature and create photographic works that capture the essence, themes, and emotions of the selected texts. This exhibition not only highlights the rich literary tradition of Ireland but also brings to light the contemporary relevance of these stories in understanding and representing communities.

title: A Georgian Salon Evening at No. 4 Merrion Square
description:

Experience Dublin's Georgian era at the historic Merrion Square and discover "Baggotonia": a nickname reflecting the bohemian spirit of early 20th-century Dublin, when the nearby Baggot Street was a gathering place for the city's literary elite including W.B. Yeats and Patrick Kavanagh. Take in some live music, readings of poetry from the time, and explore the beautifully restored Georgian building. Light refreshments served.

This event is also part of the Baggotonia Festival on September 20th and 21st.

title: A Glimpse of Tibetan Buddhism
description:
Are you curious about Buddhism, about Tibet, or both? This event will introduce visitors to Tibetan Buddhism, at the Kagyu Samye Dzong Centre in Kilmainham. It was founded in 1977, and has been offering teachings, prayers and practices on a regular basis ever since, including visits from eminent teachers from Tibet, India, Nepal and other places.

The programme Kagyu Samye Dzong Dublin for Culture Night includes, on a rolling basis across the four hours, a number of activities for visitors: listen to a short overview of the centre's history and watch videos of its founders; hear a short talk about Buddhism by the resident nun, and experience a guided meditation; have a short tour of the back garden, with its historic well and plans for a new temple; avail of a chance to offer prayers and candles for loved ones, and enjoy a cup of tea and a biscuit in the kitchen. Everyone is welcome, of all faiths and none.

Building on Culture Night's celebration of the arts and taking cues from Guinness' focus on innovation, Glasshouse has specially curated a set list of classic and contemporary songs which merge these values to present a unique musical experience. From viral hits by Chappell Roan and Charlie XCX to ageless ballads by Sinéad O'Connor and Donna Lewis, this eclectic set is sure to thrill audiences at The Guinness Storehouse on Culture Night.

title: A Journey Through History: Exploring the Iveagh Trust in Liberties, Dublin
description:
Nestled in the heart of the vibrant Liberties district in Dublin, the Iveagh Trust is a hidden gem waiting to be discovered. Steeped in history and architectural splendour, this tour promises to transport guests back in time, unveiling the secrets and stories that lie within its walls. Come along and embark on a 500-word journey through the Iveagh Trust, a true Dublin treasure.

The Iveagh Trust, founded in 1890 by Edward Cecil Guinness, the First Earl of Iveagh, is a testament to Dublin's rich heritage. As you step inside the building, you'll immediately sense the weight of history in the air. The trust was established to provide affordable housing for the working-class citizens of Dublin, and it continues to serve this purpose today.

title: A Night of Percy French
description:
Culture Night 2024 in Carrick-on-Shannon will feature a celebration of the 170th Anniversary of Percy French who was born on the 1st May 1854, in Cloonequinn, Co. Roscommon by the County Leitrim Percy French Society.

The County Leitrim Percy French Society was formed by Tish Dunleavy and Frank Cadam as they realised that, despite his extensive musical repertoire French was under-appreciated and under-promoted. The society have performed in theatres all across the country, including two sell-out shows in the National Concert Hall, the show is performed by nine members of the Society in period costume with Frank Cadam taking the role of the great man himself, in a manner authentic to the spirit and arrangements in which French himself performed. From the moment the curtains rise the audience will be transported to a world of laughter, song and timeless story telling. The talented performers breathe life into Percy French's classic works with unparalleled passion and finesse. Their dedication to preserving Irish culture and heritage shines brightly in every note sung and every line delivered. The show is a delightful journey through the whimsical landscapes of Irish folklore and the tender moments of everyday life, all expertly woven together by the society's skilled actors and performers. From uproarious comedy to poignant ballads, each item is executed with precision and heart, eliciting a range of emotions from captivated audiences. The event will serve as a joyous celebration of the 170th anniversary of Percy French's birth.

title: A Spectacular Evening of Music and Dance with Noelle Robinson and The Suzuki Violin Group
description:
The Suzuki Violin Group are students from Athy, Dublin and Tullamore. The students pride themselves on giving concerts from an early age in order to develop their technique and performance skills. In the group, all types of music are encouraged and Culture Night is a fantastic opportunity for them to show their enthusiasm and demonstration their interest in musical diversity. Come along to hear Bach's Double Violin concerto, Irish and European folk music, as well as a collaboration with Irish dancers for some reels and jigs. 

The Suzuki philosophy is based on the mother tongue method, where parents are involved in the lesson by observing and working on the detail of the lesson with the child when practicing at home. Progress is not an accomplishment of big steps but rather, each small achievement is praised. Students are encouraged to do continuous workshops, concerts and graduations to motivate their practice. The ability to practice is not a natural effort but it is developed by praise and encouragement, mostly given at concerts. Some of the students you will hear have participated in workshops in Ireland and abroad and also have preformed in the Royal Albert Hall in London.
fullAddress: Athy Community Arts Centre, Woodstock Street, Townparks, Athy, County Kildare, Ireland

title: A Stitch in Time – Upcycling Workshop
description:
"A stitch in time saves nine"

Mending and upcycling clothes is not a new idea. Past generations have been making and mending textiles down through the years, but this workshop will introduce you to the tips and skills you need to get the best out of your clothes and household fabric items. Bring along 3 -5 items of pre-loved clothes or textiles (all other materials supplied) so that they can be repaired, upcycled or recreated into something new. No sewing experience necessary. The workshop will be a mix of hand and machine sewing, showing you how to be more sustainable with your textile items. From repairing a loose stitch to adding lace sleeves or cutting down a neckline, it's all possible with a little guidance and you’ll be amazed of what can be transformed and created. A fun, creative and informative workshop suitable for all.

title: A Tour of Maynooth College Chapel at 4-5pm
description:
On Culture Night, why not book yourself in for a tour of one of the most stunning marvels of 19th century church architecture and decoration in Ireland!

Following the completion of the work on Maynooth College by Pugin and his people, the college’s attention turned to the need for a College Chapel, a campaign led by the president of the time, Charles Russell. In 1875, the foundation stone would be laid for what eventually became a building of fine and superior quality. The College Chapel is the work of two architects, JJ McCarthy and William Hague. It is the apotheosis of nineteenth century, neo-gothic architecture, design and decoration. It is human achievement of immense beauty, dedicated to Laus Deo (the praise of God). The curious and fetching arrangement of the stalls facing each other is to facilitate the chanting of the Divine Office, indicating the function for which it was conceived, constructed and completed as a chapel for the preparation and formation of students for the priesthood, of which in excess of 10,000 have been ordained since the foundation of the college in 1795.

Bookings for the 16:00-17:00 tour can be made on the following link: https://bit.ly/ChapelTour1600

Bookings for the 17:30-18:30 tour can be made on the following: https://bit.ly/ChapelTour1730
fullAddress: St Patrick's Pontifical University, Maynooth, Main Street, Collegeland, Maynooth, County Kildare, Ireland

In 1875, the foundation stone would be laid for what eventually became a building of fine and superior quality. The College Chapel is the work of two architects, JJ McCarthy and William Hague. It is the apotheosis of nineteenth century, neo-gothic architecture, design and decoration. It is human achievement of immense beauty, dedicated to Laus Deo (the praise of God). The curious and fetching arrangement of the stalls facing each other is to facilitate the chanting of the Divine Office, indicating the function for which it was conceived, constructed and completed as a chapel for the preparation and formation of students for the priesthood, of which in excess of 10,000 have been ordained since the foundation of the college in 1795.

Bookings for the 16:00-17:00 tour can be made on the following link: https://bit.ly/ChapelTour1600

Bookings for the 17:30-18:30 tour can be made on the following: https://bit.ly/ChapelTour1730

Enjoy the dress rehearsal of Grania, the Abbey Theatre's upcoming production, for Culture Night Dublin 2024. Be part of history and witness some of Ireland’s foremost theatre-makers at work as this ground-breaking play is performed at the National Theatre of Ireland for the first time ever.

Grania was written in 1912 by the Abbey's co-founder Lady Gregory. This exciting new production is directed by the Abbey's Theatre Artistic Director, Caitríona McLaughlin.

Grania is based on the Irish legend of Gráinne, Diarmuid and Fionn. A story of love, lust, power and desire, friends are pitted against each other while one woman creates her own destiny, laying bare the tension between duty and passion.

Originally from Mullingar, Co. Westmeath, Carl studied in Falmouth, Cornwall initially, and completed his BA Hons in Painting in Limerick School of Art & Design. He has written and illustrated two books, ‘Mathilda & Belligerent Blackbird’ (2015), and ‘Skippy’s Tale’ (2017).

His work is represented in the Limerick City Gallery of Art, University of Limerick (UL) and the Dundalk Municipal Art Collection. In 2018 he was inducted into the National Self-Portrait collection in the University of Limerick.

Recently, the artist’s focus has been on abstract composition, principally a series under the collective title of Earth Songs. Geometric forms and underlying structures are frequent elements, but not to the exclusion of other organic shapes and mark making. Such approaches connect the work to visual art movements and music developments of the 20th century, but also to some of the oldest known paintings in human cultures around the world.

title: Access for All Documentary
description:
'Breaking Barriers: Access for All' is an inspiring documentary from the Youth Access Film Project, led by Galway City Comhairle na nÓg and Youth Work Ireland Galway. This initiative unites a diverse group of young people from Galway City to address the challenges faced by their peers with physical disabilities.

In May 2023, a Youth Access Consultation was held to hear from young people with disabilities about their experiences in public and social spaces in Galway. Following this, funding from the Irish Human Rights and Equality Commission (IHREC) was secured to create this documentary.

The Youth Access Project aims to combat ableism and promote inclusivity. This documentary, crafted by young people, takes the audience on a journey with its participants, who share honest testimonies of living with a disability. Their personal stories highlight the barriers they encounter and the impact these obstacles have on their social interactions, raising awareness and advocating for more accessible environments.

Since October 2023, these dedicated young filmmakers have worked tirelessly, conducting interviews and filming. Nova Productions is leading the project under the direction of award-winning filmmaker Teresa Lavina, ensuring a professional and impactful final product.

'Breaking Barriers: Access for All' is a testament to the power of youth voices in driving social change. Join us in supporting accessibility and inclusivity for all young people.

Formed in 2002, the AIB Choral Society is a mixed-voice choir comprising close to 50 members. Core activities include their annual Christmas and Summer concerts, and the choir have also performed at a number of venues abroad: the Royal Albert Hall London (the Really Big Chorus) singing Karl Jenkins’ ‘Armed Man’ (2008), the Krakow Music Festival (2009), the Vienna Advent Singing Festival (2012), the Prague Autumn Choral Festival (2016), the Verona Music Festival (2019) the Costa Barcelona Music Festival in Calella (2023) and beyond Culture Night preparations are also underway to take part in the City of Derry Festival in October 2024.

description:

Peig will be surrounded by animated symbols of island life; iridescent puppets of mackerel & gannets, magical lanterns in the form of naomhógs (the island boats which were a lifeline to islanders).

As a result of Peig’s book she was often misunderstood. The event aims to bring her true essence to life, celebrating her for the world renowned storyteller, lively fun storyteller, mother & island woman she was.

title: ALBUM LAUNCH – TIME MACHINE by singer songwriter Bianca Fachel
description:
"Time Machine" – A Musical Journey Through Time and Culture
recorded at Birdland Music Studio in Knockcroghery, Ireland.

Bianca, a Brazilian-born singer-songwriter, is set to captivate audiences with her highly anticipated debut album, "Time Machine." The title was born from a gathering between family and friends and conversations about the transcendent power of music. The album serves as both a celebration of Bianca's 14th anniversary as an immigrant in Ireland and a recognition of the rich tapestry of Irish and South American cultures.
Inspired by the notion that music can transport us through time, "Time Machine" is a captivating blend of ancient Irish influences, Brazilian roots, contemporary and various rhythms. Bianca's deep connection to her native South America infuses the album with tropical warmth while maintaining a delicate balance between Brazilian music, Irish music, folk, soul and jazz elements.
"This album is a labour of love, a tribute to the transformative power of music," says Bianca. "It's a reflection of my journey as an immigrant and a celebration of the diverse music times that have shaped my identity."
With its unique blend of musical styles and heartfelt storytelling, "Time Machine" promises to be a standout debut from one of Ireland's most promising new talents. Don't miss your chance to experience Bianca's captivating musical journey – step into the "Time Machine" and let the music carry you away.

title: Alice Kyteler: Witch, Victim, or Feminist Icon by Fin Dwyer (Historian & Host of the Irish History Podcast)
description:
Alice Kyteler remains the most well-known but mysterious woman in the history of Kilkenny. Seven hundred years have passed since she disappeared at the height of the Kilkenny Witchcraft Trial, but she remains an intriguing figure.

In this presentation, historian and host of the Irish History Podcast, Fin Dwyer, explores the woman at the centre of the Kilkenny Witchcraft Trial.

Considered a heretic by her contemporaries, views of her have changed over the centuries. To some, she was a victim; to others, she is a feminist icon.

In this talk, Fin Dwyer explores who Alice Kyteler really was.
fullAddress: The Parade Tower Wing, The Parade, Dukesmeadows, Kilkenny, Ireland

title: Alice Maher – ART at the Museum
description:
Join us for a special evening of culture and conversation with artist Alice Maher.

Mayo based artist and musician Breda Mayock will present this ‘in conversation’ style event with one of Ireland’s most respected and influential contemporary artists - Alice Maher.

They will discuss Alice’s life and art and the mesmerising ‘Bee Dress’ (1994) which is on loan from the Ulster Museum, in association with the exhibition The Murmur of Bees.

‘Bee Dress’ (1994) is one of Alice Maher’s most iconic works. This small child or doll’s garment is constructed from honeybees, wax, cotton and wire and reflects on themes associated with feminism, mythology and childhood.

This is a rare opportunity to view ‘Bee Dress’ on display for a limited time and hear from the artist herself about the materials, inspiration and processes involved in creating this thought-provoking artwork.

For further details, see - https://www.museum.ie/en-IE/Museums/Country-Life/Events/2024/Q3-2024/Culture-Night-Oiche-Chultuir-2024

title: Alliance Française De Cork – Exhibition Launch
description:
Opening of the exhibition 'Unreality' by artist Michaela McCann, at Alliance Française de Cork:
Michaela McCann’s work explores absurdity and unreality through the medium of oil painting and photography. Through the use of techniques such as disjunction and displacement, Michaela conveys a sense of unreality in her work. The imagery in her work creates irrational and dream-like compositions, giving the work a sense of other-worldliness. Michaela takes inspiration from everyday life, often photographing objects or settings and taking them out of their usual contexts and then combining and juxtaposing them together in order to give the work a bizarre quality and provoke thought in the viewer. Through her work, Michaela aims to challenge social institutions by rejecting the logic and rationality of everyday life and instead embrace the nonsensical.

title: An Artistic Tribute to the Great Famine
description:
New Art Gallery - An Ríoga will hold an event in relation to the Great Famine as part of Culture Night. To commemorate this somber period in Irish history, there are many themes that link to the Great Famine; such as starvation, emigration and disease. An art exhibition event will be held on the night.

Through the stories submitted members have interpreted them to create a piece of artwork. Screening of an interview with members of Frybrook House will be exhibited on the night, to enhance the visual work on display. The house also supplied soup to the locals during the Great Famine (1845 to 1852), evidenced by a very large Famine Cauldron in the kitchen.

The gallery looks forward to exploring the Great Famine through various mediums. Most importantly, the submissions will paint a picture to the public, through an insightful and educational approach.

John Robb is all these things and more.

His recently released book ‘The Art Of Darkness - The History Of Goth’ is a worldwide pop culture best seller.

He grew up in Blackpool before punk rock came along and saved his life and he formed The Membranes - the highly influential post punk band whose current albums keep pushing forward with added choirs and textures and are critically acclaimed.

title: An Evening of Art and History at the National Maternity Hospital
description:
The National Maternity Hospital is delighted to open its doors to the public for an evening of art and history as part of Culture Night Dublin 2024. The National Maternity Hospital’s historic boardroom will be open on the night, as hospital staff take guests on a unique art and history journey, exploring the hospital through key moments in Irish history. The iconic main complex was completed in the late 1930’s, built on a row of Georgian houses and including the former Antrim House. Step into this remarkable building, where every corner tells a story. Explore the unique collection of art while discovering the rich past of the hospital which is intertwined with the 1916 rising, literary giant James Joyce and the Hospital Sweepstakes!

Entrance to the hospital for Culture Night 2024 will be via the Mount Street entrance facing Merrion Square North.
fullAddress: 2 Lower Mount St, Dublin, Ireland

title: An Evening of Classical Music
description: An evening of classical guitar (renaissance, baroque, romantic, latin) with master guitarist and tutor Thierry Fouet. Thierry takes us on a fascinating musical tour of Europe, exploring (in an accessible way) the history of the pieces he plays. For those familiar with classical guitar this will be an opportunity to see a master "at work", for those unfamiliar they may be "converted" by the end of the evening.
fullAddress: Gardens, Kilkenny, R95 KCF1, Ireland

title: An Evening of Indian Classical Dancing – Bharatnatyam Margam
description:
Immerse yourself in the rich cultural heritage of India with an enchanting evening of Bharatnatyam, a classical dance form known for its grace, precision, and expressive storytelling. Our event, ""Evening of Indian Classical Dance - A Bharatnatyam Margam,"" will feature a traditional sequence of performances, or Margam, which includes intricate dance movements, rhythmic footwork, and emotive expressions.

The evening will unfold with a series of captivating dance pieces, starting with the Pushpanjali, a rhythmic invocation, and progressing through various items such as Jatiswaram, Shabdam, Varnam, Padams, and concluding with the Thillana. Each piece is meticulously choreographed to highlight the dancer's technical skill and emotional depth, offering a comprehensive showcase of Bharatnatyam's beauty.

Our talented performers, adorned in traditional attire and exquisite jewellery, will bring to life ancient stories and spiritual themes, creating a mesmerizing experience for the audience. This event promises to be a cultural feast, celebrating the dedication and artistry of Bharatnatyam. Join us for an unforgettable journey through the timeless elegance of Indian classical dance.
fullAddress: Coláiste Muire Máthair, Saint Mary's Road, Galway, Ireland

title: An Evening of Multicultural Poetry and Music
description:
Multilingual Poetry & Music event.

To promote the belief that this rich and varied culture is alive, treasured and nurtured in people's lives, today, we will include 'Readings from poets of other cultural background including in Libyan/Arabic, Malaysian/Malay / Irish and in English languages.

In this vibrant performance project sparked by feeling, sound and imagination. We respect, support, and ensure the inclusion of all voices and cultures that make up Ireland today, from all sections of society, from existing and new communities, and from all social backgrounds, ethnicities and traditions. The audience can experience different cultural practices and traditions through poetry and music.

We will wear our local Libyan attire Libya and Malay. The poets will showcase Libyan and Malay dances accompanied by their music. This exposure can help to promote cultural understanding and foster a sense of community.
This will be an enjoyable healing experience creating musical space that connect with everyone presence. Come along and enjoy the relax atmosphere and be entertained.

title: An Evening with Kilkenny Uileann Pipers
description:
The Uilleann Pipes are recognised as a UNESCO Heritage Instrument. The Kilkenny Uilleann Pipers Club are a Kilkenny City based organisation aiming to both preserve and promote the appreciation of uilleann pipes, and the teaching and learning of Irish traditional Irish music in Kilkenny.

We will have the following two events taking place at Rothe House for Culture Night:

‘Try-the Pipes’ event gives an opportunity for those interested or curious about the uilleann pipes to come along and try them out with experienced uilleann pipe tutors from 6-7pm

‘The History of Uilleann Pipes, Pipers and Pipemakers in Kilkenny City and Surrounds’ A lecture given by John & David Tuohy and Pat Murphy), concluding with a short recital by local Kilkenny pipers from 7.15- 8.30 p.m.

title: An Evening with Patrice Davern at Cashel Library
description:
"An evening with Patrice Davern" . Friday 20th September from 6.30pm. Booking essential to 062 63825.

Patrice studied music at Maynooth University at both degree and Masters level, before taking up a place at the world-renowned Sorbonne University in Paris where she attained a professional Masters in music & performance. Patrice has toured extensively with both To Dance on the Moon and Spirit of Ireland, performing at home and in Germany, Denmark, New Zealand and Australia.

She sang as a soloist at the Eucharistic Congress in Croke Park and at the opening Mass for the World Meeting of Families and also performed for the visit of Pope Francis to Ireland, along with regular performances on RTE’s televised masses. She and her sister have performed as a duo and their rendition of the Rattlin Bog received world-wide attention receiving over 100 million views on-line and earning them an invite to perform at a music festival in Wisconsin, USA. She regularly performs with the Fuaimlaoi Choir based out of St Teresa’s Church in Clarendon Street, Dublin and has recorded a studio album and composed music for liturgical celebrations along with recording individual songs released with her sister.
fullAddress: Ladys Well, Cashel, County Tipperary, E25 K798, Ireland

Join Patricia as she engages in a captivating discussion with Claire O’Brien, presenter of the Midlands 103 arts show, exploring the inspiration behind her gripping stories and the journey to literary success.

description: A large outdoor artwork combining light, water and sound, celebrating the many traditions connected with Ireland's holy wells. Visitors are invited to contribute their own votive offering by lighting a floating boat in memory of a loved one. Unveiled at twilight, the installation will grow in size and radiance as darkness falls.

Discover the latest works by Georgina Melly, an artist inspired by the vivid colors and serene beauty of nature. From a young age, she has been captivated by the natural world, and her paintings reflect this deep connection. Through expressive brushwork and a rich palette, Georgina brings to life the colors, light, and textures that define our environment. This exhibition invites you to explore her unique perspective on the beauty that surrounds us, celebrating nature’s splendor on every canvas.

description:
The aim of Athy Film Club is to bring cinema to Athy. On the second Wednesday of every month, they screen award-winning, acclaimed and inspiring Irish and international titles with their season running between September and June.

On Culture Night, doors open at 7pm with the film commencing at 7.30 sharp. Refreshments will be served to encourage social interaction between our members. Membership available at the start of the season but tickets available to anyone wishing to attend on the night.

Family Screening.
fullAddress: Athy College, Tomard, Athy, County Kildare, Ireland

title: Au Naturel
description:
Au Naturel is a one-woman creative contemplation of the relationships we have with our bodies and with the earth. It is a journey through historical and modern-day beliefs, rituals, and cultural constructions around menstruation and aging. In a celebration of all natural rhythmic cycles - in women, in men, in the environment - this performance challenges taboos and stigmas, and promotes caring attention and sacred connection to our bodyscapes and landscapes.  
                       
The performance space is in a lightly wooded section of grass in between the Corrib Walk and the Orbsen Building Car Park. The area is wheelchair accessible with two gravel paths from the car park. Audience members are welcome to bring camping chairs for seating in this storytelling-around-the-campfire vibe. Come prepared with weather-appropriate clothing and footwear, an umbrella, and a device for taking photos for an exploration in nature as a part of the performance.

📅 7–7:50 PM Friday 20 September 2024
📍Meet at Orbsen Building, University of Galway (H91 DK59) – https://maps.app.goo.gl/zwQanRkKYupLySWa7

Developed with the support of Galway Dance, the O’Donoghue Centre for Drama, Theatre, and Performance, Galway City Council, Culture Night, and of course - Mother Earth.
fullAddress: University of Galway, University Road, Galway, Ireland

title: Author Kieran Crowley at Tipperary Town Library
description:
Kieran Crowley is a writer from Mallow, Co. Cork. He has written a number of books for children including The Mighty Dynamo and The Santa List. His debut novel was shortlisted for the CBI Book of the Year award and he has over ten years of experience giving writing workshops and presentations. He spends his free time either watching football or being dragged on walks by a giant dog. Suitable for children aged 7 and over.

**CROWD PHOTOGRAPHY / DIGITAL RECORDING RELEASE NOTICE**

If you have any questions about data protection please contact: artsoffice@tipperarycoco.ie

title: Autumn Wreath Making Workshop in Fire Station Artists’ Studios
description:
Come along on Culture Night for an Autumn Wreath Making Workshop, designed to bring people together through the art of crafting, while promoting sustainability and creativity.

We will be using eco-friendly materials such as twigs, leaves, pinecones, and other seasonal elements, and discussing ancient foraging practices, sustainable activity and the nature of the materials used while making the wreaths. Facilitated by artist Rachael Kelly Ryder.

This is a drop-in style workshop, so participants can come and go as they please. Fire Station Artists’ Studios ask that you register your interest by pre-booking.

locations.title: Dublin City - Monto And North Georgian Quarter

fullAddress: Fire Station Artists' Studios Ltd, Buckingham Street Lower, Mountjoy, Dublin 1, County Dublin, Ireland

title: Awakening Imagination – Exhibition Launch
description:
At this exhibition launch, visitors are invited to witness how artists within the Triratna Buddhist community express their spiritual practice through diverse and captivating artworks. This tradition not only embraces but celebrates the arts, integrating them into the very fabric of Buddhist practice as well as the vibrant culture of the Dublin Buddhist Centre.

Through Buddhist practice, the worlds of myth, imagination, and archetype come alive. For many people, this can produce a profound encounter with the transcendental.

There will be a reception with light refreshments as well as an introduction by Prasannadeva in conversation with some of the artists showcased.

locations.title: Dublin City - Monto And North Georgian Quarter

fullAddress: Dublin Buddhist Centre, James Joyce Street, Mountjoy, Dublin, Ireland

title: Backstage Theatre Presents – Distillation
description:
A performative journey which takes you to the Irish bog landscape through scent. Distillation is a response to the recent cessation of the peat harvesting industry in Ireland.

Over the past year, Luke Casserly has collaborated with renowned perfume maker Joan Woods to create a unique distillation of the Midlands bog – the place where he grew up – as the starting point for an olfactory encounter which looks at our human relationship to place. Dedicated to the future of our broken landscapes – in the hope that by listening to them, we might be able to better understand them.

Part lecture, part performance, the project is an ambitious attempt to look at our human relationship to landscape through scent. As an artist from the Irish Midlands, Luke was inspired to make the piece in response to the recent cessation of the peat harvesting industry, as a way of stretching out further conversations around the environmental potential of the Irish bog landscape.

Luke has collaborated with renowned perfume maker Joan Woods over the past year to create a unique distillation of the Irish bog, the starting point for an olfactory performance which attempts to translate the landscape for a live audience in an intimate and inventive way. Each audience member will be invited to smell the custom-made perfume as part of the performance.

Supported by Goethe-Institut Irland, with additional development support by IMMA, Druid FUEL, NTE and Backstage Theatre’s Activate Residency programme.
fullAddress: Farranyoogan, Longford, N39 FP46, Ireland

We will host an opening reception for the exhibition Transitus at 6pm. This is a unique opportunity to visit our artists’ studios, our exhibitions and get an insight into our artists’ work and the day to day of life of an artist. Booking for studio tours is essential. 30 min tours will take place from 5-6 pm and can be booked via the link below.

title: Bafushia (A Physically Bound Process of Forward Movement)
description:
Bafushia is a word from the Traveller Cant language that conveys a physically-bound term of forward movement. The exhibition title arose while exploring Jack Butler Yeats images of Travellers with Oein DeBhairduin and participants from the Sligo Traveller Support Group.

The exhibition consists of contemporary artists who share heritage within the Travelling community. What is important about this selection of artists however is the relevance and criticality of the work that they make. A criticality that is simultaneously rooted in personal experience, but also advocates for the sharing of diverse knowledge, experience and reflection.

Participating artists: Chloe McDonagh, Dave McDonagh, Francesca Hutchinson, Leanne McDonagh, Phien O’Phien, and and Tommy Rhattigan.

Presented in partnership with Cairde Sligo Arts Festival as part of the Hereditas Project

PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS EXHIBITION IS OPEN FROM 11 AM TO 5 PM, NOT FROM 4 PM LISTED ON THE PAGE

title: Balor Rep Presents the Wife, Her Cat and All the Other Stuff
description:
The Wife, Her Cat and All The Other Stuff is a new play by Letterkenny writer Brian Walsh, performed by popular actor and comic, Andy McGranaghan.

A husband relates a curious tale of domestic pet care, housetraining, keyboard warriors and animal psychology, moving gently to a conclusion that few could have foreseen. Along the way there are many laughs and absurd situations, with unlikely appearances by George Orwell, Donald Trump supporters, the Minister for Finance and Joe Duffy.

No booking required, (just arrive at Dillon’s Hotel on the night).

Factory (or Begley's) Lane was the historic site of a Quaker Meeting House which then became a linen ticking factory and bleaching area. It is one of the few desire paths connecting MacSwiney Quay and South Main St., leading directly to the Bandon Footbridge. It is the main pedestrian connection between the Historic North of the town and the Commercial sector in the South.

title: Bantry Library Celebrates 50 Years
description:
One of Ireland’s most beautiful buildings - Bantry Library - is 50 year old. This short film celebrates its construction by weaving together archival photography and recent audio recordings from the project architect Harry Wallace and local Murnane and O'Shea builders Donal Hunt, Jerry O'Sullivan and John O'Neill who made this space age mega-lith dream a reality.

The Library will also host two exhibitions one on the building and architecture of Bantry library from its construction in the early 1970s and the second from MTU 2nd year Interior Design architecture students from their projects on redesigning the interior of Bantry Library.
fullAddress: Bantry Library, Bridge St, Town Lots, Bantry, Co. Cork, P75 K402, Ireland

title: Barry McGovern Reads Samuel Beckett
description:
Acclaimed as one of the world’s greatest Samuel Beckett interpreters, Barry McGovern comes to Dún Laoghaire for a very special performance. Reading from selected poems and prose, Barry will bring to life the words of Beckett, highlighting the wit, humour and wisdom of the Nobel Prize winner and local literary legend.

Barry is one of Ireland’s most skilled and experienced actors, who has had a long career in theatre, film, television and radio. He is regarded by many as one of the leading exponents of the work of Samuel Beckett.

title: Be a Podcaster for a Day
description:
Throughout the evening this Culture Night, anyone interested can drop in and work with a producer to record their own 5-minute podcast in The Podcast Studios, a state-of-the-art recording studios in Dublin city centre. The podcast will then be professionally edited and sent to the podcaster that evening to share with family and friends. This is the perfect opportunity for people of all ages, backgrounds, and cultures to learn about podcast production, record a chat or an interview with a friend, tell a great story, and just have fun.

Alongside this, there will be tours of the studios to get behind the scenes of podcast production. In the café space, there will be an exhibition on the independent Irish podcasting scene and a chance to chat with Dublin podcast creators. An opportunity that can't be missed!

locations.title: Dublin City - Trinity And The Docklands

fullAddress: The Podcast Studios, Magennis Place, Dublin 2, Ireland

title: Bean Feasa Screening in TUS Athlone
description:
Athlone Family Resource Centre will be hosting a special screening of 2023 'Bean Feasa', a project that tells the stories of women through poetry, music and song.

The screening will take place in the Douglas Hyde theatre of TUS Athlone from 4pm-6pm on Friday 20 September for Culture Night.

In 2023 a local collaborative music project facilitated by Kara Richards and Bianca Fachel named 'Bean Feasa - Wise Woman' project was funded by the Arts Council "Artist in the Community" scheme, managed by Create - the national development agency for collaborative arts. The project sought to tell the stories of women through music, poetry and song. Over the course of the year 11 women from diverse cultural and socioeconomic backgrounds worked with Kara and Bianca to develop an original song that reflected on their experience of womanhood and their journey to becoming a 'wise woman'.
fullAddress: Athlone Institute of Technology, Bunnavally, Athlone, Co. Westmeath, N37 HD68, Ireland

title: Behind The Scenes in the Library.
description:
Tours beginning 6.00pm, 6.45pm, and 7.30pm.

Staff at the Central Library have spent the last 30 years gathering every article, book and author associated with Donegal in one library. It’s called the Donegal Studies Collection. During this short tour, you will learn about the resources available for you to trace your Donegal ancestors or research the history of the county. See a snapshot of Donegal as it was, from Mícheál Ó Cléirigh and the Four Masters to poteen making in Inishowen; the lives of Isaac Butt to Daniel O’Donnell and the changing landscape of the county from the first ordnance survey maps of 1835 through to the new A5. Come along on Culture Night and see some of the gems in this exclusive collection. Maximum of 10 people per tour.
fullAddress: Central Library, Saint Oliver Plunkett Road, Letterkenny, County Donegal, Ireland

title: Behind the Screens is a Museum
description:

Archive staff will be on hand to explain the stories behind the objects and their choices for display. Featuring highlights from the moving-image, documents and artefacts collections, this experience will give you a real understanding of how Ireland’s national film heritage is cared for at the IFI.

Tours take place at 18:00 and 19:00 and last approximately 40 minutes.

locations.title: Dublin City - Temple Bar And Creative Quarter

title: Belfry Tours at Christ Church Cathedral

The tour is conducted by an experienced member of cathedral staff. There is a limit of 24 spaces available for each belfry tour which must be booked in advance.

Tours take place at 16:30 and 17:30, lasting approximately 30 minutes.

Please note that latecomers will not be admitted. This tour is not suitable for those with walking difficulties, a fear of heights, claustrophobia or service animals. It is only available for people aged 12 and over. Please wear sensible shoes and do not bring any large items such as bags, etc. This ticket does not give admission to the cathedral itself.

locations.title: Dublin City - Temple Bar And Creative Quarter

To visit our Digital & Fine Metal Workshop: Come to our BS1.5 Workshop @ Unit B1B, Marina Commercial Park - Eircode T12KRH7

· demos in pattern making and shape forming in copper in our Fine Metal facility
· demos in wood turning in our Woodwork facility

Leonor Bethencourt is a tour guide with a background in theatre production and performance.

title: Between the Veils
description:
A Photographic exhibition by photographer / Visual artist Michael Croghan.

Between the Veils is a condensed personal exploration of realities in the everyday, with a focus on the fringes of place. Uncommon commonalities of local place in the midlands of Ireland, County Longford. This collection comes from a personal archive, gathered over a number of years, photographed spontaneously and opportunistically, with a tangible curiosity and intuition. Lifting the veil of usually hidden fabric of spaces that have just as much intrinsic value to place but rarely captured.

Michael will be presenting new work that will be first shown in an exhibition on culture night.

title: Blessing of Hope Orchard
description: Castleblayney has had a beautiful orchard with a rare breed of apple trees that must be protected. The orchard has withstood entire generations of Castleblayney’s rich history. Join us on Culture Night to celebrate the orchard and the heritage and history of the estate around it. Led by the Armagh Rhymers we will bless the orchard and enjoy performances of story and song relevant to the apple tree. This event will be an all-round celebration of our orchard and will raise awareness of what needs to be done to keep it preserved.

title: Block Print Fun
description:
We look forward to welcoming young print-makers to PrintBlock Callan this Culture Night, for an evening of block printing fun!

This workshop is an opportunity for children to interact with our native Irish plant and wildlife species through the fun medium of block printing upon fabric.

We will print our own individual tote bags to take home plus a collaborative banner celebrating our biodiversity using nature themed block prints designed by Michelle McMahon (artist and PrintBlock Callan technician/facilitator).

Children are also invited to bring along a light colored cotton t-shirt to print on.

The workshop is suitable for 4th-6th class children (8-12 years old).

Spaces are limited.

Booking is essential.

Please let us know if you have access requirements or support needs that would assist your visit or workshop participation.

title: Blue Of Distance
description:

Their inaugural exhibition at the Sarah Walker Gallery captures the transformative experiences of their journey, inviting viewers into the Arctic's complex environment with powerful images of its dynamic changes and profound beauty.

title: Book in a Bag
description:
Book in a Bag returns to Goethe-Institut Irland as part of Culture Night 2024.

A few hundred blue bags will be placed around 37 Merrion Square, throughout the Georgian building which houses the library, and around the modern building dedicated to the Language Department. The bags contain gems from different genres: the free treasures could be a great story, poems, an audio book, a music CD, a history book or a book on art.

After they have picked their bag, Culture Night visitors can browse the shelves of the Goethe-Institut Irland’s library. This beautiful space with a spectacular ceiling and cosy seating is open to the public and offers a wide range of media in German or English translation – including a corner just for kids and young adults. On Culture Night, visitors can apply for their free library card and borrow language learning material, movies, books, and more.
fullAddress: Goethe-Institut Irland, Merrion Square East, Dublin 2, Ireland

title: BookCrossing and Games
description:
Instituto Cervantes, the official organisation for promoting Spanish language and culture, invites the public to a special evening at their library. Located on the first floor, the library boasts over 11,000 volumes, including Spanish learning materials, literature, films, history, and a children's corner.

On Culture Night, the library will host an engaging experience with BookCrossing, puzzles, and games. Visitors can enjoy the calm atmosphere, learn new Spanish words, and gain insights into Spanish culture through fun activities.

Additionally, there is a special discount on membership for Culture Night. For €20 instead of €35, new members get a full year of borrowing privileges, access to the electronic library, and participation in online book and cinema clubs.
