title: Boyne Tradfest 2024 – Culture Night Recital
description:
Set within Embracing Vision: FNCI 100 Years, we are delighted to welcome Boyne Tradfest return, this year, with an Irish Traditional Music Recital performed by Martha Guiney (flute) and Ruairí Cunnane (guitar).
This even has limited seating, served on a first booked, first served basis.

Martha Guiney, winner of BBC NI/Arts Council NI Young Musicians' Platform Award, released her debut album, 'The Raven's Call' in February 2023. The award winning County Down flute and whistle player has toured internationally and collaborated with many renowned artists in Scotland, Denmark, Finland, South Korea, Norway, Brazil, Italy, the US and beyond.

Ruairí Cunnane is a widely sought after guitarist, singer and bouzouki player from Meigh, County Armagh. Ruairí has been immersed in the folk scene right from childhood through his father Mickey's inspiring vocals and guitar playing. His music, while mainly rooted in traditional/folk, can incorporate elements of blues and rock, creating an appealing mix of sounds which makes his playing distinctive.
fullAddress: 36 St Laurence St, Moneymore, Drogheda, County Louth, Ireland

title: Boyne TradFest Official Launch
description:
Boyne TradFest takes place from 20th - 22nd September 2024, with Drogheda bursting at the seams with traditional Irish music.

The official launch takes place on Friday 20th September at 5pm. Join Mayor of Drogheda Paddy McQuillan & event organiser Gormlaith Maynes in cutting the ribbon on what promises to be a fantastic weekend of music.

Music performances by Patricia Clark on fiddle, Séamus Ong on uilleann pipes & Rachael Dooley on harp, joined also by traditional singers.

This event is followed by a recital with Martha Guiney & Ruairí Cunnane in the Highlanes Gallery from 6:30pm, and traditional Irish music session in McHugh’s from 7:30pm.
See www.boynetradfest.ie for full schedule.
fullAddress: West Street, Drogheda, County Louth, Ireland

title: Boyne Tradfest Recital for Culture Night at Highlanes
description:
Boyne Trad Fest presents a Culture Night performance two of the most exciting ‘voices’ in contemporary trad within Highlanes Gallery.

Set within Embracing Vision: FNCI 100 Years, we are delighted to welcome Boyne Tradfest return this year with an Irish Traditiinal Music Recital performed by Martha Guiney (flute) and Ruairí Cunnane (guitar).

About

Home to Fleadh Cheoil na hÉireann in 2018 & 2019, Drogheda’s traditional Irish music scene has grown from strength to strength.
Boyne Tradfest welcomes artists and visitors from across the country for an exciting weekend of traditional Irish music, song & dance.
With over 35+ musicians performing as part of Boyne Tradfest, this exciting new festival promises to be a memorable one!

Martha Guiney, winner of BBC NI/Arts Council NI Young Musicians’ Platform Award, released her debut album, ‘The Raven’s Call’ in February 2023. The award winning County Down flute and whistle player has toured internationally and collaborated with many renowned artists in Scotland, Denmark, Finland, South Korea, Norway, Brazil, Italy, the US and beyond

Martha was selected to perform as a soloist at the prestigious BBC Proms and has also featured as the primary artist in a number of collaborative projects with The Cross Border Orchestra of Ireland (CBOI), The Irish Chamber Orchestra (ICO) and The Ulster Orchestra. Martha graduated with a First Class Honours Degree in Music at Dundalk Institute of Technology and a Masters in Traditional Irish Music Performance from the Irish World Academy, University of Limerick.

Ruairí Cunnane is a widely sought after guitarist, singer and bouzouki player from Meigh, County Armagh. Ruairí has been immersed in the folk scene right from childhood through his father Mickey’s inspiring vocals and guitar playing. His music, while mainly rooted in traditional/folk, can incorporate elements of blues and rock, creating an appealing mix of sounds which makes his playing distinctive. Highly respected internationally, Ruairí regularly tours both nationally and internationally with leading musicians within the traditional/folk circuit. Ruaíri has performed at many festivals throughout Europe and America with singer songwriter Breige Murphy, multi instrumentalist and singer Barry Kerr and flute player Martha Guiney, to name a few.
fullAddress: Highlanes Gallery, Saint Laurence Street, Moneymore, Drogheda, County Louth, Ireland

title: Bray Jazz @ St Saviour’s Church, Rathdrum
description:
Bray Jazz Festival will present a double bill programme for Culture Night in 2024, showcasing how two groups have approached, in a unique way, how traditional Irish music can be incorporated into jazz and improvised music.

Belfast-based Córas Trio are leading lights in a fresh wave of Irish musicians exploring links between the ancient and the 21st century, their music is steeped in free improv, electronic music, and trad. Navá is a group of that comprises Irish folk and bluegrass musicians who have teamed up with two Iranian brothers to explore and celebrate the ancient musical cultures of Ireland and Persia.

Notably, both groups have represented Ireland at WOMEX (worldwide music expo) , bringing their unique and distinct visions of cultural cross-pollination to life at the celebrated UK world music festival.

Navá comprise Irish banjo player Paddy Kiernan and bassist Niall Hughes, and Iranian born brothers Shahab and Shayan Coohe. They were nomination for Best Folk Group at the 2022 RTE Folk Awards.

Córas Trio comprise Kevin McCullagh (fiddle, electronics), Paddy McKeown (guitar, electronics) and Conor McAuley (drums). The Belfast-based trio are part of a new creative wave, taking Irish music to the outer reaches where the spirits of Schoenberg and Sun Ra play with Seán Ó Riada and Tommie Potts.The trio released their debut album in Dublin last month.

On Córas Trio: “…fusing Irish traditional music, collective improvisation, free jazz and human-computer interaction, four of my very favourite things in music…” New Music Fix, BBC Sounds

On Navá: "Catching them live is a must, as these tunes will surely glisten in the heat of live performance" - The Irish Times

No booking is required. For any queries, please contact: brayjazz@gmail.com

www.corastrio.com | www.navatheband.com
fullAddress: Rathdrum, County Wicklow, A67 PP98, Ireland

title: Brazil On Screen Presents: An Introductory Talk on Latin-American Cinema, Kneecap & Revolution in Irish Film
description:
Where, when, and how did people begin to use cinema as a political weapon?

For Culture Night at Pálás Cinema Galway, immerse yourself in a conversation exploring the shared revolutionary spirit in Irish and Brazilian cinema, from Latin-American ideology to Kneecap, curated and presented by Verena Barbosa as part of Brazil on Screen.

We’ll dig into how and why film has been such a powerful tool for political expression, reflecting our histories of resistance and resilience. After the talk, stay for a special screening of the award-winning Brazilian film Bacurau!

Bacurau

Director: Juliano Dornelles & Kleber Mendonça Filho 131 mins, Brazil-France, 2019, Digital, Subtitled

Bacurau, a settlement in rural Brazil, is shaken by its matriarch's death. But something strange is happening, the water supply has been cut off, and the village has disappeared from satellite maps completely. Under threat from an unknown enemy, Bacurau braces itself for a brutal fight for survival.
fullAddress: Pálás, Merchants Road Lower, Galway, Ireland

title: Brazilian Guitar Duo Gustavo de Morais and Robson Rocha
description:

The duo will take you on a captivating journey through the rich traditions of Brazilian music and the sophisticated harmonies of jazz, infusing each note with emotion and creativity. This special performance will highlight the contributions of talented women composers, offering a unique and inspiring musical experience. Don’t miss this opportunity to witness the Brazilian Guitar Duo as they pay tribute to these remarkable women through their soulful and dynamic interpretations.

This is a drop-in event which will take place in the Foyer from 5pm-6pm.
fullAddress: Riverbank Arts Centre, Main Street, Greatconnell, Newbridge, County Kildare, Ireland

title: Brian Trench on Bea Orpen – Culture Night Gallery Talk
description:
St Peter's Place as seen from the Blue School
An exploration of a work by artist and founder of the Drogheda Municipal Art Collection - Bea Orpen
by Brian Trench

Founders of the Collection, husband and wife, businessman and artist, Terry Trench and Bea Orpen,
moved to Drogheda where they would settle in the region and bring up a family and add greatly to
business, cultural, community and educational life of the area, founding the Drogheda Municipal Art
Collection in June 1946, with the support of the local authority. 60 years later, Highlanes Gallery, the
Municipal Art Gallery for Drogheda and the North East would be established, the now home of the
Collection and a dynamic programme of exhibitions and public engagement activities.

Earlier this year, we acquired a work of Bea's St Peter's Place as seen from the Blue School, the Blue
School also being the former home of the Orpen/Trench's during their early years in Drogheda.
For Culture Night, Bea's son Brian discusses this work, its curiosities in terms of its real and imagined
views of the Drogheda townscape, his mother's practice, and the heritage and history of the Blue
School.
The work will be on view for the first time as part of the Collection for Culture Night.
fullAddress: 36 St Laurence St, Moneymore, Drogheda, County Louth, Ireland

This is the culmination of an intergenerational project with fourth, fifth and sixth class students of Broadford Kilbane National School in collaboration with older people in the rural community of Broadford Kilbane in East Clare.

Children collected stories from older people in the community and wrote and illustrated the stories themselves. They will invite older people to come to a Rambling House in Broadford for a night of storytelling when they will launch their book of stories.

University of Limerick, an Age Friendly university, has also carried out research on the project and this will also be available on the night.

title: Building Bray
description:
This year Signal Arts Centre takes a look at our built environment and its evolution over time from a small village to a seaside destination and has a little fun imagining its future through film, costumes and a guided walk.

3:00 - 6.30 pm
Passers-by can paint, draw, and print on outdoor boards. All materials supplied.

6.30 pm - 7.15 pm
A short, guided, fun, walk along the promenade about the evolution of architecture on the seafront. All are welcome. Comfortable shoes and umbrellas are advised. Dressing up in eye-catching costumes encouraged.

7.30pm – 9:00 pm
Screening of two films. The first is a 10-minute work by Shane McCormack on Bray Head Hotel, followed by "A Barbershop History of Bray" by Don Rorke & David Ryan which explores the evolution of Bray from a small village to a holiday destination with the coming of the railroad.

Seating is limited so it will be on a first come first served basis.

As always Signal staff artists will be dressed up in a variety of costumes to reflect the overall theme of the event throughout the evening.

Capacity: The guided walk has no limit, and we invite passersby to paint on a large board in the lead-up to the main event. The main screening event has a limit of 30 seated.

For any queries please contact: director@signalartscentre.ie

www.signalartscentre.ie
fullAddress: Signal Arts Centre, Albert Avenue, Bray, County Wicklow, Ireland

title: CAFÉ CIRCUS
description:
Hosted by Dangan House Wine Bar, we are thrilled to invite/lure you into the exciting new theatre event Café Circus.

Maria Cunningham’s one woman comedy cabaret will showcase a cast of absurd and disturbed circus performers who travel from town to town with nothing to live off of but your validation and fish finger sandwiches.

Audience, be advised that while watching the show you might experience laughter, crying, booing (giving or receiving), feeling the sudden urge to get up and leave, making a friend, puking, texting your mother back, meeting the love of your life. The possibilities are truly endless at Café Circus. All of the above is encouraged.

This will all take place in the ambient setting of Dangan House Wine Bar. It will be a relaxed performance setting, and will be neurodivergent friendly.
Doors will open at 7:00pm and refreshments will be available from the bar before and after the show. The show will commence at 7:30 and last for approx 40 mins. The venue will be closing at 9:30pm.

title: Cairdeas Kilkenny Parkinson’s Choir at Loughboy Library
description:
A performance by the local community Cairdeas, Kilkenny’s Parkinson’s Choir. This choir’s mission is to uplift and enhance the lives of people with Parkinson’s, their families and friends. The choir plays a role in the community in that it ensures that those with Parkinson’s can participate actively in their community. It is hoped that other people can be invited who have the condition and see the possibility of getting involved in the choir in future.

Cairdeas Choir has sung in major performance venues in Kilkenny and beyond, and has become known for their interactive, joyful delivery. They recently received a standing ovation for their performance in ‘Choirfest’ this year. For this performance, they will perform some new pieces from a more classical repertoire, and will provide a varied programme which includes poetry reading, a beautiful soprano soloist, and of course, the heavenly harmonies of the Cairdeas Choir.

title: CANCELLED – BOLD: Donlon Dance
description:
PLEASE NOTE: THIS EVENT HAS BEEN CANCELLED

Choreographed by Amy Donlon along with the Donlon Dance students, BOLD is a dance piece that will focus on Contemporary floor work. With a long history dating back to the early 20th century, floor work has become a prominent feature in Contemporary dance and the movements were inspired by the human body and its connection to the earth.

BOLD aims to show strength and resilience while also using our bodies to connect softly to the floor. Contemporary dance is an expressive style that combines elements of several dance genres including modern, Jazz, Lyrical and Classical Ballet. BOLD will also feature two duets.

description:

The workshops will take place outdoors, starting in the area in front of Monaghan Courthouse and following a route to the Peace Campus.

Participants should dress appropriately for the weather and ensure they are visible in low-light conditions.

Advanced Workshop 7:00 p.m. – 9:00 p.m.

title: Care & Carelessness – a Feminist Economics Walking Tour of the IFSC
description:
The concept of this tour is a simple yet effective one: to make real the abstract nature of globalised finance by undertaking a journey through the streets where it conducts its business. It is also, at the same time, a walk through Irish history, from the War of Independence to today’s world of transnational capital. This walking tour will take you along locations from Liberty Hall into the North and South Docklands, asking: “Who benefits from the care at the foundation of our societies?”

The tour is facilitated by Financial Justice Ireland (formerly Debt and Development Coalition Ireland), a global financial justice organisation working for a fair and just society for everyone, in collaboration with CATU (Community Action Tenants Union), speakers from trade union movement, climate justice movement and more!

title: Ceiliúradh ár gceantar, Teanga agus Cultúir. Béal an Phobail.
description: Ceiliúradh speisialta bunaithe ar shaibhreas, chultúr agus teanga Limistéar Pleanála Teanga Dhún na nGall Theas. Cuirfidh an taifeadadh seo in iúl go bhfuil an Ghaeilge mar chuid lárnach den oidhreacht shaibhir sin. Beidh an ócáid seo a reáchtáil go huile agus go hiomlán trí mheán na Gaeilge. Tá sé mar sprioc againn muinín agus mórtas áite a chothú i measc iad siúd a bheas i láthair ar an lá. Tá clú agus cáil ar Limistéar Pleanála Teanga ó thaobh an ceol, an teanga agus an seanchas. Taifeadadh speisialta le ceoltóirí, amhránaithe agus seanchaithe áitiúla a bheas i gceist. Beidh na trí pharóistí ag glacadh páirt sa taifeadadh seo sé sin Gleann Cholm Cille, Cill Chartha agus Ard an Rátha. Beidh muid ag comhoibriú le Coláiste na Carraige agus na bunscoileanna le píosaí éagsúil a thaifeadadh. Beidh an físeán de na daltaí ag glacadh páirt in imeacht lán-Ghaeilge sa phobal luachmhar mar go dtarraingíodh sé aird ar spriocanna an Pholasaí don Oideachas Gaeltachta. Craolfar an léiriú speisialta seo ar leathanach Facebook ‘Béal an Phobail’ ag 6i.n. ar an 20ú Meán Fómhair.
host: Lár Comhairle Paróiste Gleann Cholm Cille

title: CEILIÚRDH AR MHICHEÁL MAC SUIBHNE le CUMANN DRAMAÍOCHTA CHORR NA MÓNA
description: Comóradh ar an bhfile Micheál Mac Suibhne (1760 - 1820) a chaith formhór a shaoil in iarthar Chonamara. Tá cáil ar a chuid amhráin An Púca, Bainis Pheigí Ni Eaghra, Murchadha Beag O Maoláin agus go leor eile, chomh maith leis an dán cáinteach Iorras Fhlionnáin. Maireann a cháil sa tseanchas i measc an phobail agus i measc muintir Shuibhne atá fós breá bríomhar in iarthar Chonamara. Scríobh an staraí Hardiman faoi sa mbliain 1846 agus bhailigh Tomás Ó Máille a chuid amhráin ón bpobal don leabhar Micheál Mac Suibhne agus Filidh an tSléibhe i 1934. Tiocfaidh aisteoirí, fonnadóirí agus gaolta leis an tSuibhneach le chéile lena shaol agus a shaothar a cheiliúradh. Páirteach beidh Cumann Dramaíochta Chorr na Móna, Máirín Uí Chéide, Orla Ní Fhinneadha, Seán O Coistealbha, Colm Seoighe agus Micheál O Gionnáin. Is duine de mhuintir Mhic Suibhne í an tOllamh Irene Whelan agus tabharfaidh sí léargas dúinn ar shaol an tSuibhnigh.
fullAddress: Station House Theatre, Clifden, County Galway, Ireland

title: Celebrate 25 Years of Vermillion Design at the City Assembly House
description:
City Assembly House are delighted to welcome the public to this special Culture Night Tour of the Vermillion Design exhibition. For anyone interested in Irish Graphic Design, this is a must-see exhibition celebrating 25 years of the creative work of Dublin-based Vermillion Design.

Visitors can explore highlights from their visual design archive in the historic surroundings of the City Assembly House, and even take a special curator’s tour of the exhibition.

Items on display include rare ephemera, postage stamp designs including the first use of augmented reality, bespoke maps for historical graveyards and zoological gardens, coins, packaging, illustrated books, branding & identity, museum exhibitions and bespoke items designed on behalf of the Irish State for visiting VIPs to Ireland.

Curator’s tours take place at 17:30 and 18:30. Early booking is advisable as spaces are limited. Self-guided tours from 19:00.
fullAddress: 58 South William Street, Dublin 2, Dublin, D02 X751, Ireland

title: Celebrate Culture Night with Creative Places Tipperary Town
description:
Celebrate Culture Night at the dedicated Creative Places art space.

An exhibition, two films, textile art and a chance to find out more about Creative Places.

Enjoy the fabulous musical visual artworks of local artist, Marion Stern, who is hosting her exhibition Soul Song, at Creative Places. Soul Song features intricately painted musical instruments that people are allowed to touch and play! Marion will be on hand to chat about her creative practice and where her inspiration comes from.

Watch two films created by local people:
Right To Be Here was a project that involved teenagers in Tipperary Town exploring their home place through drama, writing, visual arts and music. They made a short documentary about the experience.
An Eventful Day in Tipp is a short animation featuring models and stories created by the people from Moorehaven Community Centre. Both films will be playing on loop for the duration of Culture Night if you’d like to come and see them over a cup of tea or coffee.

Meet Textile artist, Gemma Morris, and find out more about her decorative stitched work with local groups and you might be inspired to get stitching yourself. Gemma will be handing out materials to people who would like to contribute to a new collaborative textile artwork.

Culture Night will also be an opportunity to find out more about Creative Places Tipperary Town and how you can get involved.

**CROWD PHOTOGRAPHY / DIGITAL RECORDING RELEASE NOTICE**
Please be aware that by entering this area, your photograph and/or digital recording will be used, without compensation, for the use in all media and you release Tipperary County Council and The Arts Council from liability whatsoever of any nature.
If you have any questions about data protection please contact: artsoffice@tipperarycoco.ie

title: Celebrating the Heart of the Traditional Irish Pub
description:
At the heart of every traditional Irish Pub lies an appreciation for music and storytelling, vital threads in the fabric of Irelands rich cultural heritage. Through music, storytelling, and lively conversation, we will celebrate culture and the pub bridging the gaps between generations, social classes, and cultures. Fostering community understanding and unity.

The evening will begin at 9pm with Storytelling in Mother Macs Public House where a local storyteller will recount local tales of myth, legend and history. While entertaining it also preserves the oral traditions that form an integral part of Ireland, stories often passed through generation with a unique local identity.

Moving outdoors to Back Lane we have planned a lively session of traditional Irish music featuring local practitioners. This session will feature the haunting melodies of fiddles, tin whistles, bodhráns and accordions. This spontaneous expression of Irish music will breathe life into the very air, captivating the community and creating intimate connections between musicians and listeners.

Following the session we return inside for Sean Nòs, an unaccompanied vocal style of singing deeply rooted in Irish Tradition. Known for its intricate ornamentation and free rhythm, Sean Nòs singing conveys profound emotion and narrative through its unique delivery.

Traditional Story Telling
9:00pm - 9:30pm

Traditional Irish Music Session
10:00pm - 11:30pm

Sean Nos
11:45pm - 12:15am

title: Changing Perceptions: Women of Art and Medicine at RCPI
description: The art collection at the Royal College of Physicians of Ireland helps tell the story of the medical profession and its personalities – including their class and gender. It is of little surprise that the paintings in RCPI's art collection are predominantly of and by men. This Culture Night, RCPI’s historic home at 6 Kildare Street will be open to allow visitors the chance to explore our art collection. The self-guided tour will take you around the building, allowing you to learn more about the women represented in the works as physicians, painters, and patients. This project brings the portraits of and by women to prominence, an important correction that demonstrates the changing role of women in history, medicine and artistic practice.
host: Royal College of Physicians of Ireland

title: Church Tours by Rev William Deverell
description:
St Maelruain's Church, Tallaght, on the south-western outskirts of Dublin, is built on an ancient Christian site with a long and distinctive history. We will have tours by the Rev William Deverell of our 200 year old

John Semple Church which joins a Norman tower. There has been a site of worship on the site since St. Maelruain founded his monastery in the 8th Century. Not long ago it was a small rural church. It is surrounded now by the shops, offices and the vast spread of new housing in this area. It stands as a symbol of eternal truths at the centre of the new town which is Tallaght.

title: City Sounds: Bang Bike Collective with Dimebag DJs and JBR Project ft. Pinsleep at Essex Street
description:
Funded by Culture Night Late, City Sounds is a late night dance event celebrating Ireland’s growing soundsystem culture. From 21:00 until midnight, experience Dublin’s streets in a brand new light with three immersive dancefloors curated by some of the island's most innovative soundsystem collectives. Each location, Central Plaza, Essex Street and Capel Street, will offer its own distinct vibe and rhythm, showcasing the rich diversity of Ireland’s electronic music scene.

Immerse yourself in the eclectic world of Bang Bike (Belfast) as they bring their unique, mobile soundsystem to life on Essex Street. This dynamic setup promises a fusion of old-school classics and high-octane live performance.

Kicking off Bang Bike’s night in Dublin, Dimebag DJs will be playing a refreshing mix of electronic, disco, acid and dirt. Later on, they will be joined by one of Northern Ireland's best electronic live acts, the JBR Project, performing with Pinsleep (Aga Olekk) improvising on violin. Together they will wrap up the night with live instrumental techno, bringing heavy Jean-Luc Ponty vibes to Essex Street this Culture Night.

From here, cross the bridge to Capel Street where Interruption (Dublin) will be presenting a line up of skilled Dublin natives that champion that classic techno sound. Around the corner at Central Plaza, witness the raw power of Rise Up Soundsystem (Cork). With a reputation for pushing the boundaries of sound, their setup will transform the plaza into a high-energy haven that is true to the roots of soundsystem culture.

Festival favourites Bang Bike are a battery-powered party-bike like no other. Hold on to your boots as this collective specialise in creating dancefloors where none have been before.

Filming and photography will be taking place at this location. By attending we assume permission unless a member of our team is explicitly notified.

title: City Sounds: Interruption with Lyndz B2B GVX, Scidley Rott and David Oblivion at Capel Street
description:
Funded by Culture Night Late, City Sounds is a late night dance event celebrating Ireland’s growing soundsystem culture. From 21:00 until midnight, experience Dublin’s streets in a brand new light with three immersive dancefloors curated by some of the island's most innovative soundsystem collectives. Each location, Central Plaza, Essex Street and Capel Street, will offer its own distinct vibe and rhythm, showcasing the rich diversity of Ireland’s electronic music scene.

On Capel Street, Interruption (Dublin) will be presenting a line up of skilled Dublin natives that champion that classic techno sound.

21:00 - 22:00 Lyndz B2B GVX
Lyndz is an Inner City Dublin hard techno DJ. She loves to incorporate elements of hip hop and breakbeat in her sets and she has a real ear for selecting obscure tracks that grab her audience's attention. She actively tries to push the younger generation to keep the scene as underground as possible.

GVX is an up and coming young DJ hailing from Estonia.GVX pulls his influence from the underground rave scene in Dublin, ranging from old school tracks far before his time to the fresher sounds of today.Expect underground sound at its finest from this 19 year old star.

22:00 - 23:00 Scidley Rott
With an impressive decade-long tenure behind the wheels of steel and more recently digital decks, Scidley Rott has honed her eclectic style by curating elements of breakbeat, hip hop sampled techno and nostalgic old skool ravey sounds into her mixes that are nothing short of hard, hectic and absolutely banging. In recent years, she has been lashing out pounding techno sets at gigs, festivals and free parties across Ireland and the UK most notably with legendary crews Interruption and Annaghtek.

23:00-00:00 David Oblivion
David Oblivion is a techno DJ and musician from Dublin, Ireland. After spending some time in the UK he became hooked on the harder side of techno that he was hearing and he started building his own record collection. He has had releases on labels such as Stay Up Forever, Bionic Orange, Polymeric, Triple A and his energetic DJ sets have seen him share lineups with artists such as Chris Liberator, Sterling Moss, Tassid, Hector Oaks and SPFDJ. He set up a club night called Interruption, which quickly developed into a record label and sound system, and has since become a strong force in Ireland's techno scene.

From Capel Street, cross the bridge to Essex Street, and see Bang Bike bring their unique, mobile soundsystem to life. This dynamic setup promises a fusion of old-school classics and high-octane live performance. Nearby at Central Plaza, witness the raw power of Rise Up Soundsystem (Cork). With a reputation for pushing the boundaries of sound, their setup will transform the plaza into a high-energy haven that is true to the roots of soundsystem culture.

Filming and photography will be taking place at this location. By attending we assume permission unless a member of our team is explicitly notified.

title: City Sounds: Rise Up Sound System with t-woc, Jwy and Jonezy at Central Plaza
description:
Funded by Culture Night Late, City Sounds is a late night dance event celebrating Ireland’s growing soundsystem culture. From 21:00 until midnight, experience Dublin’s streets in a brand new light with three immersive dancefloors curated by some of the island's most innovative soundsystem collectives. Each location, Central Plaza, Essex Street and Capel Street, will offer its own distinct vibe and rhythm, showcasing the rich diversity of Ireland’s electronic music scene.

At Central Plaza, witness the raw power of Rise Up Soundsystem (Cork). With a reputation for pushing the boundaries of sound, their setup will transform the plaza into a high-energy haven that is true to the roots of soundsystem culture.

t-woc is an Irish producer & DJ known for blending genres, both in his own productions and his DJ sets. A compulsive digger of vinyl for many years, he focuses on playing out dance floor oddities and grooves. He is one half of the party starting duo - Different Rhythm with Pablo Santo and is a regular selector for Firehouse Skank & Backstory amongst others.

Jwy is a Dublin-based DJ with roots in Ghana, India and Surinam, born in Amsterdam. She is the founder of foxgluv and was a participant in the Skin & Blister DJ workshops. Her style combines a mix of bass-heavy genres such as afro/caribbean inspired riddims, UKg, breaks, grime, drums, baile funk, and more.

In addition to his hard-won mad-skills behind the decks, Jonezy’s vast horde of ridiculous records is as fine an anthology as any in Ireland. Soulful reggae classics, hidden jungle gems, the latest Manchester hybrid halftime weapon – Jonezy mashes the dance and puts it back together with ease. In 2010, Jonezy launched his own promotion concept, Riseup! to explore a broader take on modern rave sounds and bring key, cutting edge acts to Cork. With his dad, a trained chippy, Jonezy built The RiseUp! Soundsystem, known for its heavy rumble, precision top end and is recognised as one of the best soundsystems in the country.

Turn the corner from Central Plaza to Essex Street, and immerse yourself in the eclectic world of Bang Bike (Belfast) as they bring their unique, mobile soundsystem to life. This dynamic setup promises a fusion of old-school classics and high-octane live performance. Cross the bridge to Capel Street where Interruption (Dublin) will be presenting a line up of skilled Dublin natives that champion that classic techno sound.

title: Civic Trust House – Cork Cello Collective plus Vinyl Archive
description:
Goodcellas is a friendly ensemble of members of the cello section of Cork Fleischmann Symphony Orchestra, playing music from their wide repertoire. Goodcellas will run from 7-7.40pm.
A uniquely fascinating aural journey through the Irish 20th century, in collaboration with IndieCork Film Festival will take place from 8-9.30pm. Selecting from his vinyl archive of rare 20th century Irish Classical Music, music expert John Byrne is our insightful and encyclopedic guide. John writes, I would lay claim for the beginning of the Irish 20th century as being in 1936, the year that a young gay Irish composer called Frederick May found himself fleeing Austria and the spreading tentacles of Fascism. His reaction was the penning of his 'String Quartet In C Minor'. The creation of indigenous Classical composition went very literally technicolor with the scribing of this piece. But no-one noticed at the time. Why? The answer comes down to intentional state policy. The music went unsupported by state decree. Things slowly changed in the latter decades of the last century with the appearance of Irish Classical performers and composition on records. And thus the proper beginning of our aural story. This presentation will give you the emergence of a genre of music in recorded form. Accompanying visuals by IndieCork's Tony Langlois.

Music - Cork Cello Collective plus Vinyl Archive

title: Come Journey With Us!
description:
This year, as part of Culture Night, the award-winning Donegal Railway Museum will be open until 9.00pm. In addition to guided tours of the museum, visitors can explore the renowned Donegal Steam Engine, Drumboe, Ireland’s first interactive steam cab. Experience railway models, engaging audio and video presentations and enjoy a ride on the train (weather permitting), along with fun games for all ages.

The museum is also hosting Donegal Town’s official 550th Anniversary Exhibition. This exhibit, curated by the museum, features artifacts, display units, pop-ups, and more, bringing to life the unique history of Donegal Town. Contributions from three of Donegal Town’s landmark institutions—Magee 1866, Hanna Hats, and Donegal Castle—enhance this special exhibition.

description:
Mayo Dark Sky Park is collaborating with the Ballycroy Community to present a special series of events for Culture Night 2024.

Ballycroy Community Centre will host the mobile planetarium Pale Blue Dot presented for the first time in Mayo by the Wild Nephin National Park and Ballycroy Visitor Centre together with the team from Armagh Observatory and Planetarium.

The planetarium’s name, Pale Blue Dot, was inspired by American Astronomer Carl Sagan’s inspiring quote describing the view of Earth from Space captured in 1990 by the NASA’s Voyager Spacecraft. The name captures perfectly humanity’s place in space and time in the vastness of the universe and the delicate nature of our important relationship with our planet.

There will be five shows across the evening and screenings will be of approximately 20 minutes duration. Each show will be filled on a first come, first served basis with plenty of other activities to do during the evening. Ballycroy Women’s Group will present World Food Night concurrently at the Community Centre, providing food and hospitality prepared especially for the evening. All are welcome.

For Culture Night, an especially designed "Star Trail" will also be available to experience and it will guide visitors to enjoy ample stargazing (weather dependent), biodiversity and indoor activities, as well as a dark skywalk, adjacent to the visitor centre of the National Park. At the Wild Nephin National Park Visitor Centre Special Astronomy introductions, both English and As Gaeilge will be screened on repeat adjacent to indoor astronomy activities, while at the Outdoor Classroom, will be the Under One Sky multi-sensory experience with sensory trail, telescopes and observation. For the late night owls, there will be a Dark Sky/ Stargazing Walk at 10.30pm, which will be a looped walk of approx. 1.5km (weather permitting).
venueName: Wild Nephin National Park & Ballycroy Community Centre
fullAddress: Ballycroy Community Centre, Tallagh, County Mayo, Ireland

title: Concert by Casa Forte (18:00)
description:
The Embassy of Portugal invites you to participate in a celebration of Portuguese culture with a concert by Casa Forte, followed by an informal social gathering.

Casa Forte is a new duo founded by the Portuguese singer Filipa Quintino and the Irish guitarist John Moriarty. Casa Forte explores the Portuguese music and Brazilian popular music songbook with new arrangements and some unusual selections. This performance will give special emphasis to Portuguese music and the repertoire will include songs from artists like, José Afonso, António Zambujo and Carolina Deslandes. On this occasion, Casa Forte will be also joined by the inspiring double bass player Barry Donohue.

All are most welcome, including music enthusiasts and members of the Portuguese community.

Better known to generations of Dubliners as Whitefriar Street Church, this church is home to the relics of Saint Valentine, patron saint of love. Visitors are welcome throughout the evening to visit the many shrines, including that of Our Lady of Dublin, taking time to light candles and to pause and reflect. The church is also home to the wonderful Kenneth Jones Organ, one of the finest in Dublin.

For Culture Night Dublin 2024, the Garda Male Voice choir & guests The Net Chords Harmony Group will give a memorable performance in the beautiful setting of his historic church.

The Colmcille Community Choir, previously known as the Colmcille Gospel Choir, has now reformed under the direction of Mark Bradley and have broadened their repertoire beyond Gospel.

Cór Ailigh, under the direction of Anne Nicholls, has been singing in Irish for the past 23 years and had the honour of singing earlier this year in St. Peter’s Basilica and in the Irish College in Rome.

Ceol Le Chéile (Choir of Ages) was established in March 2018 by Donegal County Council as part of their Age Friendly Programme and since 2023 has been self-funded. Veronica McCarron is the Choir Director.

title: Concert: LIE NING Live in Dublin
description:
The Goethe-Institut is delighted to host LIE NING for their Irish concert premiere!

LIE NING, Berlin-based musician, model, dancer, art director and LGBTQ+ & POC ambassador is looking at an impressive career so far, with appearances at SXSW, Fusion, Reeperbahn Festival, support slots for Raphael Saadique, Milky Chance and more. His sound seamlessly navigates indie, soul, and R'n'B, delivering timeless pop moments.

LIE NING will travel to Dublin by train and ferry as part of 'Slow Touring 2024', a resource-efficient concert tour by the Goethe-Instituts in Amsterdam, Paris, Dublin, Brussels and London, promoting sustainable cultural exchange between German and European musicians, testing alternative touring practices and combining local perspectives on climate change.

Alongside LIE NING, the Goethe-Institut is excited to host a DJ to dance the night away (details TBC).

title: Consent Chronicles: Stories of Hope, Healing, and Humour | We Act
description:
This Culture Night, join We-Consent and the Dublin Rape Crisis Centre for an evening of thought-provoking storytelling. ‘Consent Chronicles: Stories of Hope, Healing, and Humour’ will be a safe and inclusive space where voices can be heard, and experiences can be shared.

Throughout the night, different personal stories will be spotlighted that explore themes of consent, sex, sex education and more. From tales of survival and resilience to humorous anecdotes about the first time someone had "the talk," the night will balance the gravity of important conversations with moments of levity and light-heartedness.

This evening promises to be a heartfelt and engaging celebration of human experiences. Laugh, reflect, and grow together as you listen to stories that remind us of the power of sharing and the importance of understanding consent and healthy relationships.

title: Cork City Hall – Atrium – Photo Exhibition: 6-A-Side Football with interactive elements
description:
6aside is a photography series capturing in-game, first-person point of view action from Cork's community and street league football tournament.

Each week, a different player from one of the participating teams wears a body-mounted camera while playing in a different position, capturing their personal in-game experience. The resulting series tells a cohesive story of often-overlooked moments in small-sided football, while emphasising the power of football to unite diverse communities in a rapidly changing Ireland.

This year-round event takes place in The Glen, Cork city, and features players from various social and marginalised backgrounds, including those in supported accommodation, individuals at risk of or formerly experiencing homelessness, recovering addicts, residents from two international accommodation centres, former residents who have gained residency, Travelers, members of Cork's Polish, Italian, and Spanish communities, unemployed young men from the city's northside, members of the LGBTI community, support workers, journalists, and more.

The idea of passing the camera to different players was inspired by Japanese photographer Daido Moriyama’s concept of “photography by feel.” Moriyama, known for shooting without using the viewfinder, captures images based on instinct and emotion. Series curator and photographer Paul Carroll adopted this concept, entrusting his camera to a different player each week. Moreover, he involved the players in the editing and selection process.

The resulting work is a participant-driven, serendipitous blend of sport and street photography, offering a portrait of both the struggles and joys of the game as the seasons pass. It celebrates Ireland’s dynamic, vibrant, and evolving landscape while dramatizing the power of community through sport.

The Culture Night 2024 one-night installation of 6aside pays homage to Carroll's teenage obsession with football in a culturally homogeneous 1990's Ireland. Instead of posters of star footballers on his bedroom wall, this exhibition showcases members of Cork's Community and street Leagues. It encapsulates an open, multicultural, and inclusive Ireland, underscoring how sport often leads the way in reflecting societal change.

Exhibition space: A fully interactive experience featuring a foosball table for visitors to enjoy, along with a computer setup and gamepads for playing the classic video game Sensible Soccer.

An engaging, moving, and comical theatre show about memories, departures and belonging. Family friendly, but most suited to those 8 years and up.

title: Cork City Libraries – Grand Parade – Adult Lending
description:
Choral Performance from Voiceworks - 18:00 to 18:30
The Voiceworks Indie Choir is a community of female voices singing popular music. The group performs a wide variety of songs from classics such as Does Your Mother Know by ABBA to slower pieces such as Adiemus from Avatar. Known for their vibrant and positive energy, the group have performed on stage with Damien Rice at Cork Opera House and with Eimear Crehan at the Marina Market Cork.

Readings from Cork stories - 18:45 to 19:15
A reading from Cork Stories (Doire Press, 2024), an anthology of short fiction set in various locations in Cork City and County Cork, by writers who live or have lived in Cork.

ELLES MITRAILLENT EXHIBITION - 17:00 to 20:30
The aim of our project is to give a voice to women photographers so that they can free their artistic expression and, through their photographs, convey the changes that have affected their lives and share the everyday moments and decisive experiences of recent years.Our trademark is to have our photos printed on large curtains, the works exude lightness and fluidity, marking the spirit and enriching the visitor's experience. Visitors always love to “get into the photographs”.

Irene Kelleher Performance - 19:30 to 20:00
Footnote is a one-woman comedy, told from the point of view of Noreen Gilhooly, a long struggling writer who works in her local bookshop for the past ten years ago. Noreen dreams of emulating the success of her mother, the famous poet, author and feminist-activist Genevieve de Lacy. Living in her mother’s shadow hasn’t been easy, from ex-boyfriends reciting her mother’s poetry in the bedroom to customers educating her on who her mother ‘really’ was. But Noreen isn’t her mother, more into dismantling a ‘World-Book Day’ stand than the patriarchy, her only edge is refusing to floss her teeth and her greatest talent might be alphabetising the children’s section. But with the promise of a publication finally pending Noreen has to decide, is she ready to take her place amongst the literary greats or remain her mother’s footnote.

Jimmy Crowley and Eve Telford; an evening of music - 20:00 to 20:45
Come along and hear Eve Telford and Jimmy Crowley sing a selection of our Cork favorites and some Ceol and Lore is guaranteed , we are looking forward to what is guaranteed to be a great event.

Harp, voice and flute performance - 16:00 to 16:45
Nancy and Miriam Long of Ceolann, are a talented, versatile harp, voice and flute duo, who enthrall and delight audiences throughout West Cork and Munster.Nancy is the musical director of both the Skibbereen Cathedral Choir and Enchant Choral Group.She is an accomplished harpist, organist and vocalist.

title: Cork City Libraries – Grand Parade – Foyer | Climate Justice Exhibition
description:
Photographic Exhibition: Climate Justice Now - 17:00 to 19:00

Climate Justice Now! is a photo exhibition highlighting the impact of the climate crisis on communities around the world and those activists who are speaking out for climate justice. Curated by Trócaire, the exhibition shows the stark impact of climate breakdown, including the destruction and damage wreaked on those least responsible for greenhouse gas emissions. The activists featured lead campaigns on a global, national and local level, representing their communities in the fight for justice. The exhibition also features infographics with striking visuals that makes clear the injustice of the climate crisis – especially for those most vulnerable to its impacts.
Trocaire works with We Act.

description:

There will be workshops, screening of The Dragon Of Shandon 23 Samhain Parade, and a chance to explore our recent renovations which includes a purpose built stage.

See how the creative use of everyday materials can be transformed into giant floats, props and puppets. Exchange ideas with the creators, artists and designers at Cork Community Art Link, that have been making art with communities in Cork for 30 years. Explore the possibility of getting involved in this vibrant community.

Doors will be open till 8pm.

title: Cork Craft and Design – Craft Demonstrations
description:
Unfortunately this event is cancelled.

Hosted at Douglas Woolen Mills and Douglas Court in Cork City. This vibrant event showcases the rich tapestry of local craftsmanship, inviting the community to explore and celebrate the creative talents that thrive in Cork. Douglas Woolen Mills will transform into a bustling hub of artistic activity, where artisans from various disciplines will exhibit their unique creations.

Visitors can immerse themselves in the intricate world of handcrafted jewelry, pottery, textiles, and woodworking. Each piece tells a story of dedication and skill, reflecting the cultural heritage of the region.Meanwhile, at Douglas Court, live demonstrations will provide an intimate glimpse into the meticulous processes behind the craft. Watch as master craftsmen and women shape raw materials into exquisite works of art, sharing their knowledge and passion with the audience.

These interactive sessions not only highlight the beauty of handmade products but also foster a deeper appreciation for the artisans' craft.This Culture Night event is a celebration of Cork’s vibrant craft community, offering a delightful blend of tradition and innovation. Whether you're an avid collector, a curious onlooker, or someone seeking inspiration, the Cork Craft Market promises an unforgettable experience that honors the artistry and creativity of local makers.

Unfortunately this event has been cancelled

title: Cork International Film Festival – Online
description:
A special free online programme of Irish and European short films - watch online to your own schedule on Culture Night.

Discover the best of Irish and European cinema with Cork International Film Festival’s special free online short film programme! This virtual event offers a curated selection of award-winning short films that showcase the rich cultural tapestry of Ireland and Europe. Charming, captivating and thought-provoking, the programme is bound to engage and inspire film enthusiasts of all ages.
The programme will be available to book on corkfilmfest.org and available to watch from 17:00 to 22:00 on Friday, 20th September, online. After this content becomes available on Friday, 20th September at 17:00, you’ll have 12 hours to start watching. Once you begin, you’ll have 30 hours to finish watching.
Don't miss this unique opportunity to immerse yourself in the vibrant world of short films—entirely online and completely free!
fullAddress: Cork City, County Cork, Ireland

title: Cork Opera House – Immersive Experimental Sound Experience
description:
Join us at Cork Opera House for a unique auditory adventure. This late night event is a chance to be invigorated by new and experimental sounds.
Step into a world where the walls are allowed to speak. An immersive experimental audio experience. Hosted in a venue rich with history, each room offers a unique sonic journey.

Specially created for Cork Culture Night by composer, Kevin Terry, this experience is designed to transport you to another realm, where every intonation resonates deep within. As you wander through our spaces, you’ll encounter sound-worlds composed from the acoustics of each room. Some rooms feature walls dating back to 1855.
The sound interacts with the architectural nuances, creating an experience where every pulse and murmur is something that has been hanging in the air since the buildings construction.

Perfect for night owls and sound lovers.
Don’t miss the chance to immerse yourself in a world where every room tells its story through sound.
fullAddress: Cork Opera House, Emmett Place, Centre, Cork, T12 DW6P, Ireland

title: Cork Printmakers – Exhibition and Studio Tours
description:
Visit our current exhibition alongside a series of guided tours through the studios.

Reshape is an exhibition of work by 6 artists whose lives and practices have been disrupted by migration and displacement. Through print, video and installation the exhibition includes a range of responses spanning the concept of home, isolation, self-identity and community. The work was developed during the In From The Margins residency programme (2022/23), where each artist was awarded a month-long residency in Cork Printmakers, providing space to learn, experiment and develop their work. Reshape demonstrates the key role that printmaking can play in transcending cultural and national boundaries by building connections and sharing stories.

Artists: Anastasia Melnikova, Antony Reznik, Ceyda Oskay, Diaa Lagan, Leanne McDonagh, Thais Muniz.

Established in 1991, Cork Printmakers is a professional print studio, gallery and resource organisation providing artists with facilities and equipment to create artwork through the medium of print.

Event produced with the support of Lavit Gallery and Backwater Artists Group.

In From the Margins is supported by the European Commission’s Education, Audiovisual and Culture Executive Agency (EACEA), through its Creative Europe programme and The Arts Council Creative Europe Co-Funding Award.

Cork Printmakers are supported by Cork City Council and The Arts Council.
fullAddress: Cork Printmakers, Wandesford Quay, Clarke's Bridge, Cork, T12 E26D, Ireland

title: Cork Public Museum – Preserving Our Collections – Tours & Open House
description:
Cork Public Museum invites all to explore how we preserve our cultural heritage through the recent exciting acquisitions we have acquired. Museum Staff, Digital Officer Dara McGrath, and Collections Officer Mera Qamar, will examine the challenges in collecting and preserving Cork's overlooked communities and their collections.

This work has involved forming partnerships with diverse groups such as Cork African Community; LGBTQ Archive; Cork Traveller Groups, Female Voices; Our Lady's Hospital and others. Presentation will run in three individual events at 4:00pm; 5:00pm; 6:00pm. As places are limited, booking is essential. Please contact museum@corkcity.ie or 021 427 0679. Event is free of charge and open to all.

Booking is essential to guarantee seat please email Museum@corkcity.ie or 021 427 0679

Start times: 4:00PM, 5:00PM, 6:00pm
fullAddress: Cork Public Museum, Mardyke, Cork, Ireland

title: Cork Quaker Meeting House – Celebrating Culture through International Folk Dance
description: Doing line, circle and couple dances to music from around the world is a great way to celebrate the cultures from which they arose. We'll move to great music from Europe, the Middle East and further afield, and learn both traditional dances and dances using traditional steps set to modern ethnic music. No partner or previous experience needed - you can stop in for a little taster or for the entire session.
fullAddress: Quaker Meeting House, Summerhill South, Ballintemple, Cork, T12 XW8R, Ireland

title: County Cork Convicts: Tales of Transportation to Tasmania
description:
Have you ever wondered what life was like for the men and women transported from Cork to Tasmania in the 19th century? What circumstances led to their exile? How did they adapt and contribute to their new environment?

Join Heritage Specialist in Residence with Cork County Council, Shannon Forde, for ‘County Cork Convicts: Tales of Transportation to Tasmania’ to explore stories from North Cork. This presentation will delve into the historical context of transportation, guide you on accessing and interpreting convict records, and uncover individual stories of resilience and transformation.
fullAddress: Charleville Library, Rathgoggan Middle, Charleville, Co. Cork, P56 VA09

title: County Tipperary Ryan Youth Orchestra Recital
description:
The award-winning County Tipperary Ryan Youth Orchestra conducted by Michael John Ryan will hold a free public recital of wonderful Classical and modern Orchestral pieces to celebrate Culture Night 2024 on Friday 20th September 2024.
This recital will take place in St. Ailbes secondary school, Tipperary Town. The County Tipperary Ryan Youth Orchestra has performed at many festivals and toured many countries over the years including Germany, France, Switzerland, Hungary, Croatia, Italy, Spain and USA on two occasions.
They have performed in the National Concert Hall Dublin on five occasions at the I.A.Y.O Annual Festival of Youth Orchestras and succeeded in winning three achievement awards. They have welcomed visiting orchestras from abroad to Tipperary over the years most notably from Germany and West Hartford Connecticut, USA. In 2023, they held a collaborative concert with The Ealing Youth Orchestra, West London Directed by Music Director, Leon Gee. In March 2024 they performed at Roma Music Festival in Italy. In 1998 it was the recipient of an I.A.Y.O. National Award presented by The President of Ireland, Mary McAleese, at The National Concert Hall, Dublin.
Members’ ages range from 12 to 20 plus with guest musicians taking part on special occasions. Members are mainly students attending The Ryan Academy of Music and Music Schools, Colleges. The CTRYO caters for young musicians from all over Tipperary and neighbouring counties.
venueName: St Ailbes School Hall, Rosanna Road, Tipperary Town
fullAddress: Carrownreddy, Tipperary, E34 Y728, Ireland

title: County Wexford Youth Theatre
description:
County Wexford Youth Theatre presents Seven Jewish Children by Caryl Churchill

Staged and performed by ten young actors, County Wexford Youth Theatre presents Caryl Churchill’s ‘Seven Jewish Children’. The play is dense, beautiful, elusive and intentionally indeterminate. It is also direct and incendiary. It's disturbing, it's provocative, but appropriately so, given the magnitude of the calamity it enfolds in its performance. It will arouse anger and distress as it illuminates the effects war and discrimination has on children.
fullAddress: Wexford Arts Centre, Cornmarket, Townparks, Wexford, Ireland

title: CPA Ceiliúradh
description: A celebration of the rich, diverse talent of the students of Colásite Pobail Acla. Inspired by their scenic surrounds the students will perform alongside visiting International students and students from the Ukrainian community in an entertaining evening of poetry, music and dance
fullAddress: Coláiste Pobail Acla, Polranny, Achill, County Mayo, Ireland

title: Creative Writing for Beginners with David Butler
description:
Thinking of taking up creative writing? This one-hour seminar at the Irish Writers Centre will introduce Culture Night visitors to different creative writing forms including the novel, short fiction, theatre and film to help you get a taste for the prose writing form of your choice.

Leading this seminar is writer David Butler, whose novels include The Judas Kiss and City of Dis, both from New Island. His second short story collection, Fugitive, is forthcoming from Arlen House.

Throughout the year, the Irish Writers Centre offers a range of courses, both in-person and online, for writers at every stage of their career. Courses range from Beginners Fiction to Finishing your Novel, Poetry in Modern Life to Novels in Verse, the Backbone of the Short Story to the Fundamentals of Fiction.

Please note this event is a seminar and not an interactive workshop.

title: Culture Bright
description:
Scéalaíocht agus Ceol le Julie Ann De Brún 6.00-7.00 followed by a Literary panel discussion featuring renowned Poet Emily Cullen and Authors Elizabeth Reapy and Edel Coffey.

Emily Cullen is a remarkable poet who has contributed to various commemorative projects. One of her poems, “Roller Skating in Kilmainham,” reflects on the life of Grace Gifford Plunkett, who married Joseph Plunkett in Kilmainham Gaol during the tumultuous period of Irish history. The poem captures the emotions and struggles of that time. Her third poetry collection, “Conditional Perfect” (2019), received acclaim and was included in The Irish Times’ roundup of the best new poetry of that year. Elizabeth Reapy is known for her novels, including “Red Dirt” (2016) and “Skin” (2019). These works explore themes of identity, relationships, and personal growth. “Red Dirt” is set in Australia and follows the lives of three Irish friends who emigrate there. It delves into their struggles, dreams, and the challenges they face in a foreign land. “Skin” is a powerful novel that examines the complexities of mental health and self-discovery. Edel Coffey’s novel “Breaking Point” (2022) garnered much attention. It’s a gripping suspense story that keeps readers on the edge of their seats. Her second novel, “In Her Place” (2024), is set in New York and revolves around Ann, who becomes entangled in a complicated relationship after her mother’s death. When Ann meets Justin, a grieving man whose wife is still alive but gravely ill, their lives take unexpected turns.

The novel explores love, loss, and the choices we make when faced with difficult circumstances. These authors have contributed significantly to contemporary Irish literature, and their works offer diverse perspectives and engaging storytelling.

This event is a panel discussion and will be chaired by Emily Cullen.
fullAddress: Westside Library, Seamus Quirke Road, Galway, Ireland

title: Culture Night 2024 at Houses of the Oireachtas Service
description:
For Culture Night Dublin 2024, the Oireachtas Service invites visitors to join one of their guided tours of Leinster House, visit the Dáil and Seanad chambers and take the opportunity to look around a beautiful, historic building which has been recently restored.

Located in central Dublin, Leinster House is the seat of the two Houses of the Oireachtas (National Parliament), comprising Dáil Éireann (the House of Representatives) and Seanad Éireann (the Senate). It was designed by Richard Cassels, also known as Richard Castle, as the town home of James FitzGerald, the first Duke of Leinster.

Culture Night at Leinster House will have something for everyone, and we look forward to meeting families and visitors young and old to enjoy our special evening of entertainment. Tea, coffee and refreshments will be provided for guests. There will also be a dedicated Irish Language tour included in the programme for the evening.

Booking Link for the English Tour is below.

Booking Link for the Irish Tour is here: www.eventbrite.ie/e/oiche-chultuir-turas-ar-theach-laighean-tickets-1000110085187

Please note that this is a ticket only event. More tickets will be released on Tuesday 10 September at 12:00.

title: Culture Night at Academy House
description: Come and explore the Royal Irish Academy - a hidden Georgian gem tucked away on Dawson Street. During your visit to Academy House, you will see beautiful spaces such as the RIA Library Reading Room, where the earliest example of Irish writing, the 6th century Cathach, will be on display, and the Meeting Room, where the Academy’s major meetings, elections and lectures take place. During the evening, visitors will also have a chance to learn about the Academy’s research programmes and to browse the pop-up bookshop. We are also running a number of offsite events for Culture Night: Dr John Gibney, Documents on Irish Foreign Policy, will give a lecture on ‘Society & State: 1920s Ireland Through its Records’ in the National Archives of Ireland, and our colleagues in Grangegorman Histories are offering guided history walking tours of the Grangegorman site.
fullAddress: Royal Irish Academy, Dawson Street, Dublin 2, D02 HH58, Ireland

He was a journalist, teacher, editor and publisher and one of Australia's most fiery, colourful and strident 19th Century editors. Belinda's practice includes screen prints and written pieces that explore the achievements of this special Dingle man Down Under.

This will be followed by a talk by Bernard Mac Brádaigh on the genealogy resources available in Dingle Library. Then at 7.30pm, there will be music by Caroline Keane and Tom Delany.

title: Culture Night at Casino Marino
description:
Join us for a night of cultural exploration at Casino Marino!

The Casino stands out as an extraordinary building, notable for its architectural significance and rich historical context. Designed by Sir William Chambers in the late 18th century, it was intended to function as a habitable garden temple for James Caulfeild, the 1st Earl of Charlemont, situated next to his residence, Marino House, in what was then a rural setting.

This structure is recognised as an excellent illustration of neoclassical architecture in Ireland. Join our expert guides for an engaging tour of the Casino, where you will discover the incredible design and history of this hidden gem.

Guided tours will take place at 4 pm, 5 pm, 6 pm, and 7 pm during Culture Night.

Tickets for the tours are free but must be booked in advance through Eventbrite
fullAddress: Casino of Marino, Cherrymount Crescent, Marino, Dublin 3, Ireland

title: Culture Night at Dublin City Hall
description:
Dublin City Hall proudly presents an exhilarating evening of music and dance, celebrating the vibrant cultural heritage of our community. Come along for a spectacular night that promises to captivate your senses and leave you with unforgettable memories. Visitors can take in concerts from an eclectic mix of musical genres, plus stunning dance performances performed by some of Dublin's most talented local artists showcasing the richness and diversity of our cultural traditions.

18:00
Diva Voces

Diva Voces is a four-part female voice choir, based in the heart of our capital city. Their aim
is to achieve musical excellence while maintaining an atmosphere which is always welcoming,
friendly, fun and inclusive. They support women artists and performers and regularly commission
pieces from female composers. They have developed an extensive repertoire, ranging from classics
and sacred music to popular anthems, traditional Irish music, gospel, swing and folk.

****
18:30
Sollus Highland Dancers

"Traditions Meet" is an exhilarating cultural fusion that brings together the vibrant energy of marching bands, the soulful sounds of traditional musicians, and the spirited rhythms of Highland and Irish dancers from North West Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. Set against the historic backdrop of Dublin for Culture Night, this unique performance celebrates the rich, shared heritage of the island, weaving together the diverse musical and dance traditions into a night of unforgettable spectacle and unity.

****
19:30
Studio 26 Dance Academy

Studio 26 Dance Academy is a ballroom and Latin dance school based in Swords Co. Dublin. Since the age of 4 sisters Grace and Claire Garrigan had a distinct passion and talent for dance. Together they established Studio 26 Dance Academy in 2013 which has built a stellar reputation for its engaging and stimulating dance classes, and has since grown into one of the biggest dance schools in Ireland.

****
20:30
Melodic Magic at City Hall with Tony Floyd Kenna and Downtown Detroit Jon

Prepare yourselves for an unforgettable musical journey with two extraordinary Dublin songwriters, Tony Floyd Kenna and Downtown Detroit Jon, who will grace us with their soul-stirring melodies and stories in song. Among the treasures they’ll be sharing with us are beloved classics like “This Alien Has Landed,” the evocative “July,” the introspective “I Dreamed I Was A Good Man,” and the emotionally charged “Give Me A Reason.”

****
21:00
The Dublin Gay Men's Chorus is Ireland’s only all-male gay choir and brings a fresh and fun approach to choral singing offering a wide variety of music with popular songs, jazz standards, classical pieces, film music and all sorts in between!

title: Culture Night at Monkstown Parish Church
description:
This architecturally unusual church in the centre of Monkstown Village dates from 1789 and was radically extended by John Semple & Son in 1830. Semple also designed churches at Whitechurch, Kilternan, Tallaght, St Mary’s Chapel of Ease (Black Church), Abbeyleix and Killeshin. When the church opened on Christmas Day 1831, the Dublin Penny Journal claimed that "There was not a spot in the church where the eye can rest without pain"!

100 years later, Sir John Betjeman described it as ‘a cheerful Irish castle with a seaside rather than a fortress flavour’.

We invite you to come and visit the church and decide for yourself whether the above descriptions adequately describe this extraordinary building. The church is partially wheelchair accessible. Free guide leaflets, quizzes for adults and treasure hunts and quizzes for children will be available.
fullAddress: Monkstown Parish Church, Monkstown Road, Dún Laoghaire, Monkstown, County Dublin, Ireland

title: Culture Night at St. Audoen’s Church and Visitor Centre
description:
Nestled in the heart of the walled, medieval city of Dublin, St. Audoen’s Church is the only remaining medieval parish church in the capital. It is dedicated to the seventh-century bishop of Rouen and patron saint of Normandy.

St. Audoen’s Church was crucial to the life of the medieval city. Here, papal bulls were pronounced and public penances carried out. The Guild Chapel of St Anne houses an award-winning exhibition on the importance of St. Audoen’s to medieval Dublin.

Visitors to St. Audoen’s on Culture Night can take a look at the part of the church, still in use by the Church of Ireland and view the stunning fifteenth-century tomb to Baron Portlester and his wife.

title: Culture Night at The Dock
description:
Beginnings
Youth exhibition launch
Jury Room Café, 6pm

Get ready to be amazed by Beginnings showcasing the creative talents of young animators at The Dock! This fantastic display features animations crafted during a lively workshop at Staisiún Óige Ballinamore. Guided by artist Fergal Brennan, a spirited group of 10-14 year olds from the local community came together to bring their stories to life. Their hard work, creativity, and collaboration have resulted in a collection of animations that are as captivating as they are unique. Let's support these budding artists and celebrate their incredible achievements together.

A Record of Tenderness & CREATION
Guided exhibition tour
Galleries, 6.30pm

Drop in for a guided tour of our current exhibitions led by Mary Conlon, Director at The Dock. A Record of Tenderness by Richard Malone is a powerful exploration of labour and class through sculpture, performance, film and a site-specific mural at The Dock. CREATION by Deborah Kelly unfurls across generations, identities, artforms and places, and changes with each iteration, acquiring songs, congregants, iconography, poems, recipes, rules. Both artists celebrate the queer imagination.

How Can One Not Love You 2.0
Iconic short films from Ukraine
Performance Space, 7pm

How Can One Not Love You 2.0 is a selection of iconic short films about Kyiv. It includes the renowned Kyiv Frescoes by Serghiy Paradzhanov, the stunning road movie It's a Date by Nadia Parfan, the touching love story Teatralna Station by Alina Panasenko, the atmospheric Dovecotes of Kyiv by Mykhailo Volkov, the existential animation Come Outside, Masha by Yuliia Shalimova, and the impressionistic work Dedicated to the Youth of the World II by Roman Khimei and Yarema Malaschuk. The total running is 59 minutes with English subtitles.

title: Culture Night at The Leitrim Design House
description:
Elaine Quinlan – Exhibition Launch, 4-7pm

The Leitrim Design House is delighted to showcase a new exhibition Elaine Quinlan, an Irish artist living and working in rural Galway.

She paints in her studio in an area known for its marshy lowlands, rocky limestone fields and turloughs. These turloughs or vanishing lakes are the inspiration for her work, which lies somewhere between abstraction and representation. Pools, reflections, straggly grasses and mossy lichens are regular motifs in her paintings.

Working in either oils or acrylics, she builds up layers of paint with lots of glazing and delicate mark-making to create colourful, ethereal paintings on wood panels and canvas.

Living close to the Burren has also inspired her to create smaller works exploring a more graphic style - little snapshots of the colours and shapes she sees in the landscape there.

Drop-in Workshop Scarf Puppets with Rose Minnema, 4-7pm

Rose Minnema is a puppet builder and facilitates workshops to create puppets and manipulating them. Puppetry is a beautiful medium to express oneself and explore themes such as biodiversity, racial diversity and one's identity in a safe and playful way. Respect, compassion, joy and a sense of wonder about life are key elements in my work and I like to transmit that during the workshops by stimulating participants to get actively involved and use their imagination.

During this drop-in workshop in The Leitrim Design House Rose will make a selection of medium size scarf puppets. Participants will first assemble the puppets and afterwards there will be a possibility the play with them. This will give the participants a great opportunity to see something of the process of making puppets and get a sense of manipulating them. All ages are welcome to join this exciting interactive workshop.
fullAddress: Townparks, Carrick-On-Shannon, County Leitrim, N41 T2X2, Ireland

title: Culture Night at the Romanian Embassy
description:

After the film, guests are invited to explore an exhibition in the halls of the Embassy, showcasing images of Queen Marie in action. This exhibit offers a deeper understanding of why she holds a special place in the hearts of the Romanian people.

title: Culture Night at West Cork Arts Centre
description:
GALLERY TOUR: Join us on Culture Night at 4pm for a drop in Gallery Tour of our current exhibition Brian Lalor: Retrospective

STUDIO VISIT:
Our Artists in Residence will open their studios for Culture Night 2024. They welcome everyone to call in and see what they’re working on.

Studio 1: Etaoin Melville
Etaoin Melville will be showing her hand drawn stop frame animations in her studio for culture night. She will set up an installation, with projections and sound .

https://www.instagram.com/etaoins_art/
Studio 2: Noël O’Callaghan
Feathers for Rosa — This 9 minute experimental film is a unique tribute to Rosa Luxemburg, revolutionary, visionary and rebel. The film is one component part of the multidisciplinary event of the same name, which also incorporates performance, music, song, painting and poetry. It took place at The New Theatre in Dublin last March opening on Luxemburgs birthday (5th March) and ran for 3 nights. It is a collaboration between Douglas Henderson - composer, singer/songwriter, musician, performer and translator and Noël O’Callaghan - visual artist, performer, singer/musician and text writer.
Inspired by the poem ‘du liegst/you lie’ from German-Jewish poet Paul Celan, music, painting and poetry creates a lyrical homage to Luxemburg and her message of anti-militarism. This was filmed along the Landwehr Canal in Berlin where Rosa's body was thrown following her murder at the hand of the far-right Freicorps. White Feathers collected from the Berlin canal swans symbolise the struggle for peace during WWI. Juxtaposed with Emmeline Pankhurst’s White Feather Campaign, they transform this erstwhile badge of shame into a symbol of defiance and peace in Rosa's name.
A selection of paintings from the Feathers for Rosa exhibition will also be displayed and the artists will be present to answer questions on Luxemburg, Paul Celan and their life in Berlin before and after the fall of the wall.
https://www.instagram.com/thesketchoftheday/

Studio 3: Mark Beatty
‘Using a map, projector and Google Maps Street View I offer participants the chance to travel on The 'Purple' Road and see West Cork in a new light.’
https://www.instagram.com/thepurpleroad/

On the last Thursday of every month, the Galway-based band, Meet The Fawkers host a blues jam for musicians in the city in the beautiful surrounds of The Cellar bar. The night has grown from strength to strength over the last number of months, with a list of attendees ranging from complete beginners to some of the best players in the country. Attendees get the chance to play 4 or 5 blues classics in a fun and supportive environment while making new friends and improving their playing along the way.

To celebrate the success of the night and to recognise the wonderful talent in this city, the Blues Jam will be having our biggest night yet on Culture Night where we will take over the basement of The Cellar, dim the lights, crank up the amps and hand the stage over to the wonderfully talented musicians of Galway. All instruments will be provided on the night, all are welcome and the event is free of charge.

So whether you want to play or listen, join us for 2.5 hours of blues classics on what promises to be one of the highlights of Culture Night.
fullAddress: The Cellar, Eglinton Street, Galway, Ireland

title: Culture Night Celebrations with Cahir Comhaltas
description:
Cahir Comhaltas will deliver two programmes of music and dance on the 20th of September 2024 for Culture Night Celebrations.

The first one will take place in St Pauls Church of Ireland Cahir at 7pm. Here we will have our U/15 Ceilí Band and Grúpai Cheoil musicians performing with their tutors highlighting traditional music and dance. St Pauls is a lovely venue with great acoustics and a joy to perform in. Our Fear an Tí will be present to greet the audience. This event will be well-advertised in the children’s local schools and by text to all our contact groups within our branch. We will also put it into local radio, newspapers and on our social media pages. Posters will also be displayed in shop windows, tourist office and Cahir Castle.

Then from 8.30pm to 11.30pm we will hold a second recital with our older musicians and dancers, these will comprise of our Seisiún performers who play in Cahir Castle all summer ranging in ages from 15yrs. to adult. The owners of the Shamrock Lounge lend to all Cahir Comhaltas events, a mighty traditional session will be played and enjoyed by large crowds over the course of the night. This event will again be advertised on the same channels as our earlier one.

Shamrock Lounge Cahir Eircode: E21WF59
St Pauls Church of Ireland Cahir: E21VH59

description:
Led by Waterford legend Joe Meagher discover the origins of the Barker family, their estate and the origins of Waterford's, and one of Ireland's first, Art Centres. See for yourself the security 'Money Drop' from the banking days, a view of the extensive gardens the Barkers owned and take a trip through the artist's studios where art is being created probably while you walk!

There are two tours:
18.30
20.00
